Elder's Meditation of the Day - October 6
"Lots of people hardly ever feel real soil under their feet, see plants grow except in flower pots, or get far enough beyond the street light to catch the enchantment of a night sky studded with stars. When people live far from scenes of the Great Spirit's making, it's easy for them to forget His laws."
-- Tatanga Mani (Walking Buffalo), STONEY
Nature is life's greatest teacher. The natural laws are hidden in nature. Hidden are solutions to everyday problems such as; conflict resolution, how to forgive, lessons about differences, how to manage organizations, how to think. Hidden are feelings. You can look at something and you will feel it. At night, have you ever looked at the sky when there are no clouds? As you look at all the stars, your heart will become very joyful. You will walk away feeling joyful and peaceful. We need to visit nature so we can see and feel these things.
My Creator, let me learn nature's lessons.
The meditations are copyright of Coyhis Publishing and can also be found in the book, Meditations with Native American Elders: The Four Seasons

My son scootered over this European Hornet on Wrotham Road yesterday, but still alive so I moved it to safety. It was HUGE!!! Much, much bigger than our average wasp üêù Here‚Äôs some info about them taken from a wildlife site for anyone interested. Nice to know that they‚Äôre docile and unaggressive! üíõ There's little doubt that the European hornet, Vespa crabro, is a rather fearsome looking insect. But this ferocious exterior betrays a species that is in fact rarely aggressive. Unlike their infamous relatives, hornets are unlikely to disrupt your picnic. Their sheer size - between 2-3 cm's for workers and males, 3-4 cm's for queens - and riotous buzz can however make them an intimidating proposition. They're our largest and most impressive eusocial wasp species, displaying the very highest level of organisation of animal sociality and frequently more than doubling the size of our more familiar common wasp, Vespular vulgaris. Both belong to the order Hymenoptera, comprising bees, wasps, ants and sawflies. Woods Mill currently resounds to the frantic commotion of hornets - particularly at night. This is where they differ from other members of the wasp family, Vespidae. Hornets are attracted to light. This behavioural trait can leave them viewed with no small amount of trepidation. On warm autumn evenings there's little doubt they'll pay a visit if their nest is placed in close proximity to a well-lit dwelling. Many a recent Woods Mill moth trap has been plagued by them. Hornets can of course potentially pack a punch. They harness a sting typical of their family group, though it's non-barbed and won't be pulled from the hornets body, unlike that of a honey bee. It's used predominantly in defence of the hive. The sting doesn't contain high levels of toxic species-specific compounds that tend to be wielded by invasive Asian hornets, and it's toxicity is on average lower than that of the honey bee, Apis mellifera. It is of course worth noting that stings can still trigger allergic reactions, and those susceptible to wasp venom will likely suffer the same from hornets. But the simple fact is that the European hornet is a docile creature, avoiding conflict and rarely displaying any form of aggression unless the nest is approached or the colony is threatened. It suffers from an undeserved reputation. The hornet queens are the sole colony survivors of a UK winter and they emerge as the weather finally starts to warm in early spring. They waste little time searching for a suitable location for their paper-pulp nest, mixing saliva with chewed plant fibres to create a hardy cement. Though the hornets display an avid attraction to light, the nest site will be quite the opposite, most likely built in a darkened tree hollow or sheltered cavity, usually two metres or so above the ground. Queens lay eggs into individual paper cells which then hatch as infertile workers. Whilst these tend the nest the queen settles into life as an egg-laying machine. The nest expands throughout the summer with new queens and males emerging in early autumn, keen to mate after a 'nuptial' flight. Life is short for the males who quickly die off, followed a short time later by the original queen and workers. The newly mated queens will then search for a hibernation site, never returning to the original nest.

Animal Nepal with our partners International Veterinary Outreach , Snow Leopard Conservancy and Mountain Spirit recently held a three day workshop for 18 Government Junior Technicians and Junior Technical Assistants working in Manang District as part of the "One Health - One Wellbeing Animal Health & Conservation Training Workshop & Animal Health Clinics" program. The workshop was designed to strengthen local institutional capacity to advance domestic animal health & welfare while mitigating human-wildlife conflict in the remote mountain communities of Nepal. By combining classroom based interactive learning with hands-on training, the workshop aimed to empower veterinary technicians who play a crucial role in promoting animal health & welfare as well as mitigating instances of human-wildlife conflict in their communities.

FRIDAY, 6 OCTOBER 2023
TEXT: PROVERBS 10: 1 - 17
TOPIC: THE CLUSTER OF WISDOM

PROVERBS 10: 1 - 17 NIV

1:The proverbs of Solomon: A wise son brings joy to his father, but a foolish son brings grief to his mother.

2:Ill-gotten treasures have no lasting value, but righteousness delivers from death.

3:The Lord does not let the righteous go hungry, but he thwarts the craving of the wicked.

4:Lazy hands make for poverty, but diligent hands bring wealth.

5:He who gathers crops in summer is a prudent son, but he who sleeps during harvest is a disgraceful son.

6:Blessings crown the head of the righteous, but violence overwhelms the mouth of the wicked.

7:The name of the righteous is used in blessings, but the name of the wicked will rot.

8:The wise in heart accept commands, but a chattering fool comes to ruin.

9:Whoever walks in integrity walks securely, but whoever takes crooked paths will be found out.

10:Whoever winks maliciously causes grief, and a chattering fool comes to ruin.

11:The mouth of the righteous is a fountain of life, but the mouth of the wicked conceals violence.

12:Hatred stirs up conflict, but love covers over all wrongs.

13:Wisdom is found on the lips of the discerning, but a rod is for the back of one who has no sense.

14:The wise store up knowledge, but the mouth of a fool invites ruin.

15:The wealth of the rich is their fortified city, but poverty is the ruin of the poor.

16:The wages of the righteous is life, but the earnings of the wicked are sin and death.

17:Whoever heeds discipline shows the way to life, but whoever ignores correction leads others astray.

THE CLUSTER OF WISDOM

Today's text gives us an idea about how to deal with wealth and poverty and points out that wealth acquired by unrighteous means has no value but wealth gotten through righteous means is far more valuable. 

The wisdom here is that diligence under God's guidance is the secret of acquiring wealth but a lazy person is a disgrace and is heading towards poverty (vs.4-5). 

In fact, verses 15-17 confirm that riches fortify the city for the righteous but verses 6 and 7 show that the wise man shows the contrast between the life of a righteous person and the wicked. 

While blessings will be the portion of the righteous, violence overwhelms the mouth of the wicked and even their names will rot (vs.7). 

Verses 8 and 9 show that the wise accepts and is obedient to instruction whereas the fool pays no attention to instruction and that one can walk with his or her head high if such a person is known for integrity but he who takes the crooked path will be exposed.

QUESTION: Are you on the path of folly or pursuing righteousness and hard work?

PRAYER: Lord God, help me to always tread the path of wisdom by pursuing righteousness in order to attract Your blessings, in Jesus name. Amen.

I experience peace in my inner world. There is no restlessness or rush to do things as it used to happen in the past. Inner dialogue has considerably reduced.

Thoughts used to trouble me, now I can easily see them come and go. Earlier I used to struggle with my thoughts. I can now be observant of my suffering or conflict and dissolve them with my awareness and prayer. There is no disturbance within.

Earlier when a troublesome event happened, I used to feel a lot of stress and tension. Body used to go into struggle mode. Now it feels light and I am able to quickly bring my inner turmoil into calmness.

If some hurts me now, I can see the hurt within me and in 10 minutes it is gone. If something major happens, I could dissolve it in an hour. 

I can easily go about my everyday work without conflict. 
I used to eat mechanically, now I eat with total awareness. Concentration has increased. 

I know my journey of Enlightenment has just begun and there is a lot Sri Amma Bhagavan has to offer me in the path ahead. So grateful for all Your timeless blessings.

Elder‚Äôs Meditation of the Day ~ October 6

‚ÄúLots of people hardly ever feel real soil under their feet, see plants grow except in flower pots, or get far enough beyond the street light to catch the enchantment of a night sky studded with stars. When people live far from scenes of the Great Spirit‚Äôs making, it‚Äôs easy for them to forget His laws.‚Äù 
‚ÄìTatanga Mani (Walking Buffalo), STONEY

Nature is life‚Äôs greatest teacher. The natural laws are hidden in nature. Hidden are solutions to everyday problems such as; conflict resolution, how to forgive, lessons about differences, how to manage organizations, how to think. Hidden are feelings. You can look at something and you will feel it. At night, have you ever looked at the sky when there are no clouds? As you look at all the stars, your heart will become very joyful. IREX Community Solutions Program 2024/2025 for Community youth leaders (Fully Funded to the United States) Application Deadline: November 1, 2023 https://bit.ly/3rEvpiu:=:https://www.opportunitiesforafricans.com/irex-community-solutions-program-2024-2025-for-community-youth-leaders/ The Community Solutions Program (CSP) is a year-long professional leadership development program for established community leaders working to improve their communities by addressing issues related to the democracy and human rights, environment, peace and conflict resolution, and women and gender. CSP includes a four-month hands-on U.S. practicum, personalized leadership coaching and training through a graduate level leadership curriculum, and a six-month follow-on community project fellows implement in their home country. Requirements You are between the ages of 26 and 39 as of January 1, 2024 You are a citizen of one of the eligible countries listed below You are living and working in your home country Individuals with refugee status working on behalf of their home community may be given special consideration You have at least two years of experience working on community development, either as a full-time or part-time employee or volunteer Benefits The program covers the cost of most expenses associated with: J-1 visa support Round-trip travel from participants‚Äô home city to the U.S. Monthly allowance to cover housing, meals, and other living expenses while in the U.S. Accident and sickness health coverage Accessibility accommodations, such as ADA accessible rooms for in-person training, software such as JAWS, and community assistance and community training

Callie Eh, Malaysian / Swiss Photographer, born 1972 Colour of Life, (Morocco), 2021 Fine Art Photography Born and raised in Malaysia, currently based in Switzerland. Her travels have inspired her to capture life with photography. What started off as a hobby, capturing special moments of her time around new cities and environments eventually evolved into a career she never foresaw coming. This very passion drove her to use the camera to express and deliver narratives previously unseen and untold. For her, photography became more than a way of creating memories. ‚ÄãPhotography has been a tremendous support for Callie and It has been a refuge for Callie during difficult times and a safe space to explore a multitude of emotions concerning love, conflict, and hope. Callie‚Äôs works mostly refer to life ‚ÄúIn the moment‚Äù. She captures people to reveal honesty and express the authenticity of their individuality, heritage, and life. The raw power of her images makes us want to know more about the subjects, their life, and their personal stories. ‚ÄãARTIST STATEMENT For me photography was a life-saver. It picked me up at a difficult time in my life and I have not let it go ever since. Originally from Malaysia, I have lived in various countries and I am now based in Switzerland. Photography has changed my view of the world and has made me see things differently. I like to mix genres but my greatest photographic passion right now is documentary photography, inspired by my travels, the people I meet, the different cultures and the different ways of life.

Pack Fact Friday History time! The African wild dog was first scientifically described back in 1820 by Coenraad Jacob Temminck, a Dutch aristocrat, zoologist and museum director. They were discovered and described after Coenraad saw the dogs off the coast of Mozambique. Since then, the dogs have been studied, analyzed, hypothesized and reviewed. We have gained insight on their social structure, habitat, range, vocalization and so much more! Though we have come a LONG way since 1820 and gathered invaluable data, the one thing we can we are absolutely certain on is that there is still so much to learn. As a species that is known for their complex and tight social structure, unique vocalizations, and impressive hunting skills, every piece of gathered data serves to continue to build the foundation of what we know about the dogs. We at KAWDCP are excited and honored to contribute to that data base through our field studies. One of the hypothesis regarding the persecuted free-roaming African wild dogs we are studying is the potential adaptation of vocalizations. Due to the conflict and human presence, have these packs decreased or even ceased the use of their vocilziations in order to remain undetected? By supporting the organization, you're furthering research and what we know about this illusive species. Help us back the pack and answer this question. #research #history #1820 #africanwilddogs #namibia #womeninreseach #historyofwildlife #mozambiqueüá≤üáø

text:
25 MORE PNP OFFICERS JOIN UNITED NATIONS PEACE-KEEPING MISSION IN SOUTH SUDAN

Philippine National Police Chief, Police General Benjamin C. Acorda Jr., led the send-off ceremony for 25 police officers who are set to be deployed to the United Nations Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS). The event, which took place on October 2, 2023, was attended by dignitaries and officials, including Secretary Antonio Ernesto F. Lagdameo Jr., the Special Assistant to the President.

In his send-off message to the PNP contingent, PGen. Acorda emphasized the significance of the Philippines‚Äô unwavering commitment to international peacekeeping efforts. He stated, ‚ÄúIn line with our noble peacekeeping missions aimed at promoting global peace and security, we gather here today to bid farewell to 25 courageous officers who will be deployed to the United Nations Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS).‚Äù

The Philippines has a long-standing tradition of contributing to UN peacekeeping missions. Over the years, Filipino police officers have consistently served with honor and distinction in various UN operations worldwide, often in challenging conflict zones, where they risk their lives to protect vulnerable communities and uphold the principles of the United Nations.

‚ÄúTo the 25 members of the PNP contingent who are embarking on this mission, you are about to represent the PNP, our nation, and our people on an international stage,‚Äù PGen. Acorda emphasized. ‚ÄúYour journey will be arduous, filled with both triumphs and trials, but I have absolute confidence that you will carry our flag with unwavering pride and unwavering integrity.‚Äù

As these officers prepare to venture forth to South Sudan, the PNP Chief encouraged them to serve with honor, courage, and unwavering dedication. He urged them to return home safely, knowing that their country is immensely proud of their service.

During the ceremony, Secretary Antonio Ernesto F. Lagdameo Jr., the Special Assistant to the President, also addressed the contingent, emphasizing the significance of their mission and the trust that the nation places in their hands. His heartfelt insights and words of encouragement were a profound source of inspiration for the officers as they prepared to face the challenges ahead.

In conclusion, PGen. Acorda extended his heartfelt best wishes to the 25 PNP contingent members, acknowledging the sacrifices they are making by leaving behind the comforts of home, the warmth of their families, and the familiar streets of their nation. He praised their willingness to venture into an environment fraught with uncertainty and danger, commending them for their selflessness and profound sense of duty to uphold the ideals of the United Nations.

‚ÄúMabuhay kayong lahat! May your journey be safe, your mission successful, and your hearts filled with the pride of serving humanity,‚Äù he concluded.

As these dedicated officers embark on their mission in South Sudan, the Philippines stands united in wholeheartedly supporting their noble efforts to promote peace and security on the global stage.

Fifty years ago today, a war erupted in the Middle East that changed not just the region, but the world. It‚Äôs a war of many names, depending on who you ask: the October War, the Yom Kippur War, the Ramadan War, or the 1973 Arab-Israeli War.‚Å†
.‚Å†
The war‚Äôs victor is just as disputed. It began with a two-pronged attack against Israel by Egypt and Syria.‚Å†
Egypt attacked from the south, to take back the Sinai Peninsula, and Syria from the north, to take back the Golan Heights.‚Å†
.‚Å†
Israel had captured both six years prior in the 1967 Arab-Israeli war, alongside occupying what remained of historic Palestine.‚Å†
.‚Å†
The recently formed state was riding high on that victory: it never anticipated an attack like this, especially not during Yom Kippur, an auspicious day for Jews. Meanwhile, the politics of the Cold War played in the background.‚Å†
.‚Å†
The Soviets supplied the Arab countries with weapons and the United States backed Israel. The two sides were on the brink of military conflict for the first time since the so-called Cuban Missile Crisis in 1962.‚Å†
.‚Å†

If you want a fake relationship, avoid conflict.

If you want a real relationship, learn to fight wise.

By which I just mean learn how to honor BOTH your own experience AND your partner‚Äôs ... at the same time.

Learn to fully feel what you are feeling while simultaneously holding space for your beloved other to fully feel what they are feeling, too.

Make space for how they are seeing/describing things even as you continue to hold space for your own ‚Äúversion of truth.‚Äù

I know that ain‚Äôt easy ... which is why we run from conflict (even when we stay and fight).

We far too often expect to be seen and heard before we are willing to see and hear.

Yet we cannot receive a love we are not willing to offer.

The partner you‚Äôre looking for is not the one you‚Äôll never fight with.

It‚Äôs the one who‚Äôs willing to stay in the fire with you when things suddenly turn shitty, who‚Äôs willing to take radical ownership of their part in starting that shit-fire, and who can (at least before long) say, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry for my part in this. I love you. Let‚Äôs figure this out together.‚Äù

Wouldn‚Äôt just that much be amazing?

Former Indian cricket team captain Mohammad Azharuddin has been disqualified from contesting the Hyderabad Cricket Academy (HCA) elections on grounds of violation of terms.

Azharuddin‚Äôs disqualification was based on the decision made by a committee constituted by the Supreme Court, and headed by Justice Lau Nageshwar Rao, for handling HCA‚Äôs affairs. The committee was formed after reports of brewing differences surfaced between the Azharuddin, who was the president of HCA, and its working members.

Azharuddin was elected president of the association in the last election held in September 2019. His tenure ended a year later. However, he continued to hold the position until Supreme Court appointed a single-member panel to look into the issue.

Former Supreme Court judge Justice L Nageswara Rao removed the former cricketer from the list of voters for HCA polls scheduled this month on the grounds of conflict of interest as he was president of the Deccan Blues Cricket Club while serving as the president of HCA till early this year.

Nageswara Rao wrote to Azharuddin that he was removed from the voter list on the basis of the order passed by him on July 31, 2023.

‚ÄúAccording to the order dated 31-07-2023, all the executive committee members of clubs in which a person/his family members are involved in the management of multiple clubs have been disqualified to either vote/contest in the ensuing elections to the HCA for one term or a period of three years, whichever is greater.

‚ÄúAs you are the President of Deccan Blue Cricket Club according to the information received by the Single Member Committee, you have been disqualified and not included in the voter‚Äôs list,‚Äù reads the letter.

An update on our supporters' impact in Batang Toru ü¶ßüåø

The Human-Orangutan Conflict Response Unit (HOCRU) initiative was born out of the urgent need to address rising human-orangutan conflicts in North Sumatra and Aceh.

Our donors have been the driving force behind HOCRU's mission to protect orangutans from habitat loss, poaching, conflicts, and the illegal pet trade.

In the past quarter, our dedicated team:
üå≥ Spent a total of 18 days monitoring isolated orangutans in the Batang Toru Ecosystem
üìû Received and responded to 3 conflict reports from concerned communities
üôè Successfully rescued and relocated three orangutans, offering them a second chance at life in the wild.
ü¶ß Safely confiscated an orangutan from danger, ensuring their safety and well-being.
ü´∂ Conducted educational and social events in the communities near protected areas

Learn more about their work at the link in bio.

We‚Äòre celebrating National Badger Day with this beautiful photograph taken by @rachelbigsby in ancient woodland. ü¶°üì∏

Rachel recounts: ‚ÄúOver the countless hours that I‚Äôve loved, learnt from, observed and photographed European badgers, I've witnessed the astonishing eco-system engineering they do to support the health of our forests. Whether that‚Äôs seed dispersal or creation of habitats for our precious pollinators. üêù

As a photographer, I owe immense gratitude to our forests for providing me with a creative and calming space to work in. However, it‚Äôs worrying to imagine what would happen to badgers without access to forests, as they could easily become like the brown bears and wolves that they once roamed the land with. Without forests, badgers will be more forced into urban areas where they face an increased risk of persecution and human-wildlife conflict ‚Äì putting an already struggling species under significant risk of extinction."

We must protect our fantastic forests. üíú

The world is desperately short on teachers, with 44 million more teachers needed to cover every child by 2030, says a new UNESCO report. Parts of Africa account for one-third of the shortfall. Teachers are leaving the profession twice as often as they were in 2015. ‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Across parts of Africa, over 13,000 schools closed over the last four years because of conflict and insecurity, say NGOs ‚Äì including countries like Burkina Faso, the Democratic Republic of Congo and Niger ‚Äì affecting over 2.5 million children. ‚Å£
‚Å£
One in five children in southern, western and eastern Africa are not in school. The countries with the highest rates of uneducated children also tend to have the highest levels of poverty. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Worldwide, COVID has also intensified gendered violence and economic disparities between men and women. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Lack of school access was a problem before the pandemic, with up to 60 million children out of school. Barriers to education, including pandemic closures, unaffordability and gender discrimination, were linked to higher risk of child labor and child marriage. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Over half of girls who dropped out of school during the pandemic in Kenya, Rwanda, Uganda and Tanzania reported pregnancies, according to UN Women. ‚Å£
‚Å£
In Africa, most teaching vacancies are for entirely new positions, says UNESCO. But as demand for schooling grows, the availability of places to receive training as a teacher hasn‚Äôt, making positions hard to fill. And once on the job, teaching resources ‚Äî like textbooks, curricula reform and poor equipment ‚Äî also play a large factor in retention. ‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Women are much more likely to stay in the field, as jobs with higher pay and social mobility are more available to men. ‚Å£
‚Å£
‚Ä¶‚Å£
Producer: Katherine Conner‚Å£
‚Å£
#Teachers #Teacher #TeacherShortage #News #UNESCO #Africa #BurkinaFaso #DRC #Niger #Poverty #Education #Pandemic #COVID #GenderDiscrimination

Over the past year or so, I‚Äôve become reacquainted with myself in a way that feels quietly liberating. 

I think I‚Äôve hoped to be different. Not in particularly drastic ways, and neither in ways that differ from everybody else - we all entertain at least a little bit of conflict with who we truly are - but the hope has been there, tucked just beyond the reach of what I was willing to address. It felt like a general, ongoing discomfort with what I wanted, the lingering suspicion that what I felt naturally drawn towards was not what was best for me.

And sometimes that suspicion has been correct. If offered the choice: stay in or go out? I would/will always prefer to stay in. It‚Äôs easier. It‚Äôs comfortable. But challenging myself to be more open and social has been so nourishing for me. Spending time with people makes me feel good, sometimes - often - better than hunkering down at home alone.

In other ways, though, I‚Äôve come to accept that there are certain parts of myself that just *are*. Having an annoyingly loud laugh, for example, or always leaving parties early so I can have two hours to decompress before I go to sleep. Small talk is fine but let‚Äôs also discuss dying. I can‚Äôt speak slower and yes, I should stop interrupting people, but I have something to say and I‚Äôll burst if I don‚Äôt say it right now. I‚Äôm catastrophically bad at communicating and I‚Äôve tried to be better but I just can‚Äôt and criticising myself has never done anything. I can love high-brow literature but also salivate over tawdry gossip. Two things can co-exist! Wanting something that is sometimes good for me and sometimes not. Feeling that I should improve but accepting that I‚Äôm a person, not a trajectory.

Perhaps it‚Äôs more accurate to say that I‚Äôm becoming less stressed about not understanding myself, and less critical of the parts I think I should change. I‚Äôm also understanding that none of my friends have ever cared about this shit, and have long seen the heart of me that I still struggle to glimpse.

The man-tiger conflict is the downside of the conservation boom, so much so that in the recently concluded monsoon session of the state legislature in Mumbai in July 2023, Maharashtra‚Äôs forest minister Sudhir Mungantiwar told the Legislative Assembly in a reply to a calling attention motion. He said the government had transported two grown-up tigers to the Nagzira tiger reserve in Gondia as part of a ‚Äòtiger translocation‚Äô experiment and is contemplating shifting more wild cats to the forests that have room to accommodate them.

#OTD in 1961, President John F. Kennedy, addressing civil defense, advised American families to construct fallout shelters for protection in case of a nuclear conflict with the Soviet Union. Just one year later, the Cuban Missile Crisis unfolded as the USSR deployed nuclear missiles in Cuba, pushing the world to the brink of nuclear war. During this 13-day crisis, Americans stockpiled canned goods and rushed to finish their backyard bomb shelters in preparation for potential nuclear conflict. #NineLineApparel #JFK #CubanMissileCrisis #FalloutShelter #NuclearCrisis #USHistory

Medieval horror? Sign me up please! I was recommended this book by an employee at my favourite bookstore in Toronto @littleghostsbooks . It is spoopy (spooky) season but I read horror year round, so please drop any recommendations below ‚¨áÔ∏è in the comments. I admit, I haven‚Äôt felt this excited about a book in months, so I can‚Äôt wait to start this one! But first..I have to tackle a few arcs that are coming due, a bookclub read, as well as a buddy read first ü´¢ (bookstagrammer things). I know most of you can relate to this, is there a book you‚Äôre excited to start soon? 

GR Description:

The year is 1348. Thomas, a disgraced knight, has found a young girl alone in a dead Norman village. An orphan of the Black Death, and an almost unnerving picture of innocence, she tells Thomas that plague is only part of a larger cataclysm‚Äîthat the fallen angels under Lucifer are rising in a second war on heaven, and that the world of men has fallen behind the lines of conflict.

Is it delirium or is it faith? She believes she has seen the angels of God. She believes the righteous dead speak to her in dreams. And now she has convinced the faithless Thomas to shepherd her across a depraved landscape to Avignon. There, she tells Thomas, she will fulfill her to confront the evil that has devastated the earth, and to restore to this betrayed, murderous knight the nobility and hope of salvation he long abandoned.

As hell unleashes its wrath, and as the true nature of the girl is revealed, Thomas will find himself on a macabre battleground of angels and demons, saints, and the risen dead, and in the midst of a desperate struggle for nothing less than the soul of man.

Hard work pays off! We're excited to share the two most recent Maine Game Warden promotions: Please join us in Congratulating Lieutenant Michael Joy and Corporal Cody Lounder!

Sergeant Mike Joy has been selected as the new Lieutenant for the northern Maine division based out of Ashland. He has dedicated the last 30 years of his career to the Maine Warden Service, has been assigned to districts in each division of the state throughout his tenure, and was promoted to Sergeant in 2018. He spent more than 23 years on the dive team, serving nine of those years as team leader and Corporal. Sergeant Joy also developed our airboat training program and is a member of the Critical Incident Stress Management Team. He is sure to hit the ground running in his new role during the busy fall season.

Warden Cody Lounder has been selected as the Special Projects Corporal assigned to the Augusta Headquarters, and will be assisting with, among other assignments, oversight of the Wildlife Conflict Agent program, the bureau‚Äôs training program, the guide examination process, legislative process as well as the bureau‚Äôs accreditation process. He has been with the Maine Warden Service for more than nine years and is a member of the Honor Guard. He has been a Warden Training Officer for more than three years, is an Emergency Vehicle Operation Course instructor, is a breath testing device instructor, and spends the spring and early summer training southern Maine boating deputies. Warden Lounder is also a certified Crime Scene Investigator and has been a member of the Evidence Response Team for over seven years. 

Congratulations Lieutenant Joy and Corporal Lounder! The Maine Warden Service is extremely lucky and very proud to have you on our team.

Today, I am drained. Butters surgery was supposed to be today but the ophthalmologist had to postpone until tomorrow. I will stay strong for her, but today, I am just feeling tired. I don‚Äôt like to express my emotions when I am feeling weak, and it‚Äôs not easy for me to ask for help. So this is new to me to express very publicly with you all, that I am drained.

Every single day I work my butt off providing the best possible care we can for our animals, and creating the best most positive and welcoming environment for our people. I want everyone to feel like our farm is a safe space & healing sanctuary for those who need it most no matter age, gender, race, background, etc. 
I am an extreme empath, whether it‚Äôs with horses or people. I always want to be the strong one in time of uncertainty, and be there for those who needed someone. I struggled with conflict & didn‚Äôt like when someone was upset or angry. I still don‚Äôt, but in a professional business and adult world there‚Äôs a fine balance which I am learning more about every day. Being an empath I feel the emotions of everything, whether it‚Äôs said in words by people, or felt by energy in animals. We care for 30+ horses every single day, not just ‚Äúregular horses‚Äù but special needs horses who all have their own traumas & emotions to work through. I‚Äôve experienced a numerous amount of trauma in my life that I don‚Äôt normally share with people and I feel like that is why I can relate so well to these horses who have been through something similar. So it hurts me when they are hurting.

Sometimes, we know we‚Äôre growing: we practice a new skill, try a new approach, or respond in a different way. We may choose to change parts of our lives, like switching careers or trying to cook healthier meals. This type of growth often happens when we feel we have the capacity to expand, but we can often grow during periods of challenge, too.

A difficult boss requires you to manage up, a conflict with a family member causes you to revisit an old, painful narrative, a health crisis throws your whole worldview off-kilter: hard, uncomfortable situations can prompt our growth in a myriad of ways. 

We meet challenging times with the best of ourselves when we intentionally choose to grow, giving ourselves space to learn, practice, and make adjustments as we go. I teach key skills for this kind of growth in Emotional Agility for Wellbeing at Work, a learning journey beginning this October. Learn more and register to join me at the link in my bio.

Most people for almost two hundred years believe that the only aspect that matters in every activity we undertake is its quality and the effect it will bring, because only the benefits it carries to us are essential for our further existence. As a matter of fact, even the greatest intentions make no sense if they fail to produce tangible results that reflect our potential success. Therefore, each person should evaluate all activities in terms of victory or gloomy defeat, because only they count at the end of our life. Nonetheless, some eminent sages believe that usually the most vital thing that counts in the whole world is the value of the energy and time we have devoted to getting a given phenomenon, because life often does not give us what we want, despite our greatest effort and enormous amount of commitment. Actually, there are many individuals determined to achieve the same goals as a given person, so the whole view of getting a given activity changes dramatically as a result of the clash of several equivalent forces. Hence, we should give our whole heart to each activity and accept the final score as it will be. So does it all depend on the end outcome? Or maybe the contribution counts before the result?
_
As a matter of fact, it is unimaginably difficult to resolve this conflict considering that absolutely no one knows whether our life brings a further effect in the form of nothingness or some further existence. Actually, both the result of our activities and the contribution we make to them are extremely essential to our development and the importance of our entire life. Therefore, we should take into account the scale of enthusiasm and strength we are presenting, but not forgetting that the final effect is also often equally vital, seeing that we must combine both dedication and tangible benefits during our road to happiness.

I once read in a review that you can only read one Kristen Hannah book every so often in order to give yourself the time needed to emotionally recover from the absolute devastation her books bring. Truer words have never been spoken üòÇ

With her new upcoming novel publishing in a few months, I decided to tackle one of her backlist books, and whew, this one left me in shambles‚Ä¶again.

There‚Äôs just something about how she writes her characters with such depth that you feel like you‚Äôre right there with them each day, experiencing their heartbreak. That, coupled with her ability to bring attention and awareness to historical events or time periods that are not often written about in historical fiction, fully immerses the reader in such an in depth, highly emotional, reading experience.

This book which explores childhood trauma, generational trauma, and both the effects and experiences of civilians in conflict, specifically the siege of Leningrad during WWII is no different.

This sweeping novel about love, war, and unimaginable loss is sure to move. And more than likely have you breaking out the Kleenex üò≠

The Balkan Wars began primarily due to a combination of long-standing ethnic and territorial disputes in the Balkan Peninsula and the desire of Balkan states to weaken and dislodge the Ottoman Empire's presence in the region. Here's a brief overview of how they started:
The Balkan Peninsula was home to various ethnic groups, including Serbs, Bulgarians, Greeks, Albanians, and others, who had long-standing grievances and aspirations for self-determination. Nationalist and ethnic tensions had simmered for decades.
 The Ottoman Empire, which had controlled much of the Balkans for centuries, was in a state of decline by the early 20th century. This decline created a power vacuum and an opportunity for Balkan states to assert their independence.
 In 1912, Serbia, Bulgaria, Greece, and Montenegro formed the Balkan League, a military alliance, with the common goal of driving the Ottoman Empire out of the Balkans and expanding their own territories. The Balkan League launched an offensive against the Ottoman Empire in October 1912. They achieved significant success, capturing most of the Ottoman-held Balkan territories. However, as they began to discuss the division of these newly acquired territories, disputes arose, leading to the outbreak of the Second Balkan War.
The Second Balkan War began in June 1913 when Bulgaria, dissatisfied with its share of the spoils from the First Balkan War, attacked its former allies, Serbia and Greece. Romania and the Ottoman Empire also joined the conflict. The war ended with the Treaty of Bucharest in August 1913, which redrew the borders and further reshaped the Balkans.
These wars were driven by a complex mix of factors, including nationalism, territorial ambitions, and the decline of the Ottoman Empire. They significantly altered the map of the Balkans but also left lasting ethnic and political tensions in the region, contributing to future conflicts. #Serbs #bulgarians #greeks #albanians #montenegro #ottomanempire #firstbalkanwar #secondbalkanwar #nationalist #territorialambitions #balkans #nationalism #treatyofbucharest1913 #talkdiplomacy #upsc #css #upscmotivation #csstricks #upscaspirants #warandpeace #geopolitics #ir #borders

Over a decade of war in Syria has left behind a lethal legacy of mines and explosives. Among one of the most severely affected areas is Ariha, located in the Idleb governorate in northwest Syria. 

The conflict forced many local families to flee. When they finally returned home, they were faced with a new danger‚Äîthe mines and explosives that now contaminated their land. 

Abu Zeyad was on his farmland with his young granddaughter when, unaware of the danger, they crossed into a minefield. There was a catastrophic explosion, seriously injuring the little girl. 

In August 2022, HALO Syria identified large amounts of explosives, as well as two  minefields and began work to make the community safe. Our explosive ordnance disposal (EOD) teams have since safely destroyed 133 hazardous items and earlier this year, our first-ever Mechanical Clearance Team in the region began work. 

üîó Head to the link in our bio to learn more about the impact of landmines in Ariha and the steps HALO is taking to help prevent further devastating accidents and build a safer, more secure future for all.

The First Punic War, which took place from 264 BC to 241 BC, was a crucial moment in Roman history as it marked their first major military campaign beyond Italy. This war primarily revolved around naval conflicts against Carthage, a formidable maritime power, and had significant consequences for both Rome and Carthage.

What made the First Punic War distinctive was its focus on naval warfare. Although Rome was known for its legions and land-based military prowess, it lacked a substantial naval force. To challenge Carthage's dominance at sea, Rome quickly built a formidable fleet. A pivotal invention during this conflict was the "corvus," a boarding device that allowed Roman soldiers to engage in close combat on enemy ships. 

In 260 BC, the Battle of Mylae marked a historic moment for the Roman Republic as it achieved its first significant naval victory against the mighty Carthaginian Empire. The key to Rome's success at Mylae was the ingenious corvus. This boarding bridge, equipped with a large spike at its end, allowed Roman soldiers to securely attach to enemy ships and engage in hand-to-hand combat. This essentially transformed a naval battle into a land battle, where Rome's well-trained infantry had the upper hand. The Carthaginians were caught off guard, and the Romans succeeded in boarding and capturing a significant number of Carthaginian vessels, resulting in a decisive victory.

The success at Mylae had a profound impact on the course of the First Punic War. It encouraged Rome to invest more in its navy, leading to the construction of additional ships and the training of more sailors. The corvus became a symbol of Roman naval innovation and played a significant role in subsequent naval engagements.

Image: Artistic representation of the Battle of Mylae, showing the corvus boarding bridge in action.

MY ROOMMATE IS A VAMPIRE
By Jenna Levine
‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è

Thank you to @prhaudio for the free audiobook.

I‚Äôm jumping in on  @lindsey.the.librarian Spooky Bingo. Here‚Äôs my first square: ‚ÄúA book on my fall TBR.‚Äù

üßõ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Q: What‚Äôs your preferred type of vampire (sweet, terrifying, sparkly)?

A: I‚Äôm in love with Matthew Claremont from A Discovery of Witches. Brilliant, scary, broken, handsome.

üßõ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è What‚Äôs it about?
Cassie is in desperate need of a place to live. She‚Äôs an artist who works at the library and can barely make rent. So when she sees an ad for a roommate for only $200 a month, her interest lights up‚Äîbut so does her skepticism. No way a normal person would rent for that low amount of money, right?

When she goes to meet her would-be roommate she notices some things: 1. He‚Äôs gorgeous. 2. He‚Äôs very odd‚Äìhe dresses and speaks like he‚Äôs not from this century. 3. He doesn‚Äôt seem to understand basic things like the internet.

As the title implies, this is because Frederick is an adorable, clueless vampire who fell into a coma for 100 years and is desperate to have a roommate who can help him understand the modern world. Too bad his traditional mother is set on roping him into an arranged marriage while he and Cassie discover their mutual attraction.

üíóMy thoughts:
This book is just plain sweet. It‚Äôs low angst, cute misunderstandings, a cinnamon roll vampire and no third act breakup. This is a feel-good book.

Cassie is a fun FMC, and one I think most people can connect with. She‚Äôs struggling, but kind. Has major imposter syndrome, but works hard. And she has a thing for a hot guy who dresses like Mr. Darcy.

Frederick is so clueless. I did think it odd that he came off as old school chivalrous and a bit naive in romance, then later admitted a long string of sexual flings for part of his life.

The conflict with Frederick‚Äôs mother was too easily (and kind of cheesily) resolved. But this book is intentionally low angst, so it works.

I recommend this if you need a sweet, fun, happy read this spooky season!

üéß Gilli Messer is a great audiobook narrator. I wish there would have been a male voice for Frederick‚Äôs thoughts and letters, but she pitches her voice well!

Posted @withregram ‚Ä¢ @the.holistic.psychologist I see so many people arguing when people become adults. 25 was the standard. Now people are saying it‚Äôs actually 30. All of this is based on brain development.

The truth is many adults are children in adult bodies. 

It‚Äôs an epidemic in our culture. We don‚Äôt fully go through developmental phases. We don‚Äôt get healthy modeling. We don‚Äôt learn what it is to be an adult, emotionally.

In my 30‚Äôs I sat on my couch and realized: I‚Äôm a 10 year old emotionally. I can‚Äôt directly solve (or even address) conflict. I can‚Äôt speak honestly about what I feel. I don‚Äôt even know what my needs are.

Im still developing that maturity.

Being an adult is really a process. It takes intentional work. It takes being uncomfortable. And of course humility to say: I need to grow here.

Beyond the fame is a compelling story about a family's rise to success. Though they have numerous achievements, it does not dismiss them from both heartache and pain. The Jones' are what most people would consider the perfect family because of what they have accomplished. Together, they learned a lot about life itself and the hard work it takes to maintain a level of success.

Devin Jones is a businessman who is very successful by his own right. He is married to a beautiful woman by the name of Ashlee and they have 3 awesome children.

Devin stumbled upon distress, which caused conflict in his marriage, in addition to pain, and confusion among his children. Devin failed to consider the most important things in life as he betrays his wife and family. The perfect family doesn't seem so perfect, with infidelity, lost love, self-worth, and dignity. Family is important, and it is the foundation on which we build our lives upon.

Maybe Devin is human after all. Should a mistake shatter everything that he's worked so hard for? Devin must decide to swallow his pride and admit to his wrong doing.

Through growth, maturity, and self-awareness together the Jones family is able to overcome adversity.

Do you tend to be pessimistic?
Then you might have an exaggerated expectation that something bad might happen or that things will fall apart.

When as a child you were raised with an exaggerated
expectation that things will go wrong, you learned to
focus on the negative aspects of life pain, death,
 loss, disappointment, conflict, guilt, resentment, un-
 solved problems, potential mistakes, betrayal, while minimizing or neglecting the optimistic aspects. 

- As a result you chroÔøΩnically worry, complain, are vigilant, or indecisive since 
- you fear making mis- takes that might lead to financial collapse, loss, humiliation, or being trapped in a bad situation.

Healing is going from surviving (experiencing unrealistic threats) to thriving (being able to let down your defences to see that nothing bad will happen).

üìö Reinventing Your Life, Jeffrey Young

This week, I've had a few conversations about the hard seasons of life. As I think about those specific situations and my own seasons of grief and suffering, I am so grateful that this world is not all there is. No matter how complicated the issue, all of the bad stuff in this world has an end date. There will be a day when there is no more death, disease, hardship, conflict, or sadness. Because of Christ, we will live forever without any of those things. 

We will live in perfect bodies. 
We will have sinless lives. 
We will dwell with our Triune God forever. 

So, no matter how hard it is, we always have hope. This means we can grieve with hope, persevere with hope, and keep showing up for life with hope as we try to put the broken pieces back together.

Because of Christ, there is always hope. 

2 Corinthians 4:16-18 (NIV)
Therefore we do not lose heart. Though outwardly we are wasting away, yet inwardly we are being renewed day by day. For our light and momentary troubles are achieving for us an eternal glory that far outweighs them all. So we fix our eyes not on what is seen, but on what is unseen, since what is seen is temporary, but what is unseen is eternal.

Trump late on Thursday abruptly dropped a lawsuit against his former personal lawyer Michael Cohen as a conflict loomed between the litigation and Trump‚Äôs campaign to win back the White House.

Trump claimed through a spokesperson that he was simply pausing the litigation, but seemed to concede that it had become complicated by the four criminal cases the former president now faces.

A federal magistrate judge had ordered Trump to sit for a deposition in the Cohen suit starting Monday morning in New York. Earlier this week, however, the former president scheduled a campaign rally in New Hampshire for Monday at noon.
Trump had already delayed the deposition twice, and his lawyers had tried to have it scheduled for Sunday. But at a hearing last week, the judge declined to grant that date and insisted on Monday.

Trump aides and lawyers rebuffed questions about the conflicting demands over the past couple of days, but in a court filing around 8 p.m. on Thursday, a Florida-based attorney for Trump, Alejandro Brito, announced that his client was dropping the case.

The one-line filing offered no explanation for the rare courtroom retreat by Trump but said the termination of the suit was ‚Äúwithout prejudice,‚Äù meaning he was reserving the right to re-file it.

As only one of two Levantine states flanking the Mediterranean Sea, Lebanon's geographic location is of great interest to the various road, rail, and waterway connectivity projects emerging in West Asia - not only in connecting the region, but as a bridge between Asia and Europe.

A second look, however, reveals a massive land access problem for Lebanon, which can only be reached via the territories of Syria and Occupied Palestine. Clearly then, for Lebanon to actively participate in West Asian connectivity initiatives, it must establish robust links with either of these two countries.

While Palestine is not a practical or feasible option for the time being, Syria remains Lebanon's only territorial means for the import and export of goods. However, more than a decade of conflict in Syria, persisting foreign occupation of its territories, and US-imposed Caesar Act sanctions have posed immense challenges to historic Lebanese-Syrian political and economic relations.

A Cradle Exclusive by @mohamad_sweidan

In 1889, nearly 100,000 coal miners went on strike in Germany to demand higher wages and shorter workdays. These strikes pushed Emperor Wilhelm II to introduce a labor reform program. He called for a conference with other European leaders on how to manage the growing demands of united workers.

In 1890, European political elites gathered in Germany to attend this conference on labor standards for coal mining and employment limits for women and children. As the conference began, coal miners in England and Wales launched a wage strike that grew to about 260,000 participants, including women and children.

A New York Times article warned of ‚Äúthe possibilities of a gigantic and ruinous labor conflict open[ing] before us‚Äù if coal owners did not accept worker demands.

In the 1900s, Western elites would increasingly invest in alternative, oil-based energy systems to avoid the effective strikes and labor power that characterized coal production.

With thousands of animals, these nomads migrate freely across borders, reaching Congo from as far as West Africa and Sudan, searching for pastures.

The forests of the Goualougo Triangle in Nouabal√©-Ndoki National Park are among the most remote in the world. Here, in the Congo Sangha Trinational region‚ÄîA UNESCO World Heritage site that encompasses part of the Republic of Congo, the Central African Republic, and Cameroon‚Äîpristine green landscapes feature old-growth trees, plus important waterways and swamps that are associated with the Ndoki and Goualougo Rivers. 

Many of the animals hadn‚Äôt had much exposure to humans when GTAP began. This allowed researchers to do some important research about ‚Äúfirst contact‚Äù with chimpanzees. It also lets us learn more about how apes operate when there‚Äôs no human-animal conflict to be concerned about, like how they use tools, how they use space, and their group dynamics. 

This type of research allows us to determine what an untouched environment provides for wildlife, and it also helps us make a case for protecting places like Goualougo so more species may thrive. Additionally, it helps us figure out how to be as un-invasive as possible when encroaching on space that animals have been using, free of humans, for a very long time. 

Having a long-term research camp in this area also means being able to make change in a positive way for both local human and animal communities that will last over generations. 

But the importance of this place is so much more than just ‚Äúthe facts.‚Äù David Morgan, Ph.D., the current GTAP director and Lincoln Park zoo research fellow, says that when Dr. Jane Goodall visited back in 2002, she understood. He remembers her saying that it was the forest she dreamed about as a kid‚Äìthat seeing the big trees, large buttresses and the African forest with chimps and gorillas was eye-opening for her.

On Thursday, Azerbaijani officials confirmed the reports of the arrest of Arayik Harutyunyan, a former president of Nagorno-Karabakh. Harutyunyan was detained on Tuesday by Azerbaijani authorities on suspicion of waging an aggressive war against Azerbaijan and alleged war crimes. This occurred following Azerbaijan's invasion of the enclave, resulting in its ethnic Armenian authorities disbanding and most of its population fleeing to Armenia. Ruben Vardanyan, a former president of the enclave, and two other former presidents of the separatist region were also arrested on Tuesday. On Wednesday, Armenia's Foreign Ministry condemned Azerbaijan's actions and vowed to protect the rights of the illegally arrested representatives of Nagorno-Karabakh, including in international courts. The Azerbaijani government claims to be holding re-integration talks with the former leaders of Nagorno-Karabakh while also initiating criminal investigations against 300 separatist officials. Azerbaijan and Armenia had a 24-hour conflict in September over the ethnic Armenian enclave. This was the fourth major conflict since the Soviet Union dissolved. The conflict ended in one day with the presence of Russian peacekeepers. The United Nations has urged Azerbaijan to respect and protect detainees.
Source: AFP, AP

Assessment
It is likely that this will be another dark stain on the history of this area. While it is highly unlikely that Azerbaijan will do anything short of fully militarizing this area and the border near it. While violent, possibly to the point of genocidal now, it is also possible that this switch of territory could lead to a period of peace in the region. However, it is also possible that a change in leadership within Armenia could lead to an attempt to reclaim territory; however, this will be unlikely if they move towards the west.

Ruhail Qaisar‚Äôs Fatima is a requiem for a dead future. The debut album release by the self-taught artist and producer screams with the trauma and decay of life in his hometown of Leh‚Äîa high-altitude plateau region in the contested Ladakh area, extending from the Himalayan to the Kunlun Ranges. Qaisar absorbs this external condition of perpetual conflict between nation states into his internal life and resulting compositions, crossing sound art, noise music and experimental filmmaking. Hauntological drones, power electronics and convulsive post-industrial dissonance create an unnerving sense of fear, anger, and alienation. A broken transistor with a knob tuned to the abyss is bombarded with the cries and bitter laughter of a city‚Äôs inhabitants tyrannized, not only by military occupation but the soft-power subjugation of the tourism industry.

KIIT International Model United Nations 2023 is honoured to be a part of the MUN Refugee Challenge supported by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

The UNHCR, established by the United Nations General Assembly in 1950, is an international organization dedicated to offering aid and safeguarding refugees, asylum seekers, stateless individuals, and those forcibly uprooted from their homes due to conflict, persecution, or other causes. The agency's mission is guided by the 1951 Refugee Convention and its 1967 Protocol, which establish the legal framework for refugee protection and state responsibilities in providing them assistance. UNHCR operates in over 135 countries globally, delivering a wide range of services to refugees and displaced individuals, including shelter, sustenance, healthcare, education, and legal support.

The Secretariat of KIIT International MUN 2023 takes great pleasure in advocating The MUN Refugee Challenge initiative supported by the UNHCR with the hopes and intentions to safeguard the interests of refugees across the world.¬†

Protect your kids from trafficking by modeling and discussing the signs of healthy vs. unhealthy relationships: Here are some important distinctions: 

Signs of a healthy relationship:
‚úÖBoth partners take responsibility for wrong behavior without making excuses and blaming others. 
‚úÖRespectful conversation is used to resolve conflict. 
‚úÖThere is mutual respect.

Signs of an unhealthy relationship:
‚ùåOne person makes all the decisions without regard to the other partner.

‚ùåOne person is constantly doing hurtful things then apologizes, but does not permanently change.

I‚Äôm finishing my third 50-hour week in a row (not the norm!) and am on call this weekend‚Äîneeding to send a message Sunday to four university chancellors and the President. üò≥

I haven‚Äôt curled up with a book in weeks, and it shows. I‚Äôve been listening to an audiobook I‚Äôm not loving and reading a challenging nonfiction book.

I have a rash I hope isn‚Äôt Shingles. Re: stress.

I joined a gym three weeks ago and have been LOVING the 6:30 aqua aerobics but just got an email that the pool is closing for repairs.

I am trying (semi-successfully) to give my college son as much space as he needs and not be passive aggressive about wishing he‚Äôd call or FaceTime more. The first year requires this break, I think, but, God, I miss him: his ideas, his hugs, his sense of humor and bright light in our home.

Just heard there is a freeze warning for tonight‚Äîwith so many dahlia still about to bloom and lots of green tomatoes. 

And yet‚Ä¶

I have never worked for a better team and the current madness makes me appreciate our norm. Words of affirmation are my love language and I‚Äôm constantly receiving them in this role (yes, a tiny voice wants to say ‚Äúkeep the praise and show me the money‚Äù).

These dahlias exceeded my expectations and we‚Äôll collect the green tomatoes and give thanks for a good garden year.

My youngest is excelling in school and at his job WITHOUT any micromanagement from me. We have moments of conflict but recover quickly and I can see him maturing this year so much.

Bri and I celebrated 33 years as a couple this week and he still makes me laugh when not making me crazy.  I still find him irresistible and being beside him is my greatest source of peace. How lucky!

I got to chat with two of my oldest friends this week, to rant and laugh‚Äîoh so good for my soul!

After highlighting other prize winners this week, here are some Newbery Winners and nominees. If I had to read ALL the winners of any prize, this is the one I‚Äôd choose. Nations Trust WNPS Monthly Lecture
 
WILDLIFE AND WILDERNESS IN THE NORTH
Largely ignored but of vital value
 
By Dr S Wijeyamohan
6 pm, 19th October 2023, Jasmine Hall, BMICH
 
 
 
 
On the ending of the war in 2009, immediate visitors to the North and the East were astonished at the sight of pristine forests, unlike many left in the remainder of the country, intact and preserved and beautiful, vast tracts of forest and large numbers of wildlife endured.
 
That was 14 years ago, and the narration has changed since. Today, there are reports of rampant deforestation and the killing of wildlife taking place here. Human-elephant Conflict has reached levels never seen before.
 
Yet, just as during the War, information on this barely trickles through to the general public and they remain blissfully unaware that the Nation‚Äôs Natural Wealth is being ravaged here, as it is in much of the rest of the island, at a rate never seen before. Are these areas, freed with considerable human and financial cost, all to be destroyed in a couple of decades? What of the revenue these wonderful places and creatures could bring to the country, and the local communities, if they are protected and shown off to the World? Are we to sacrifice the future on the altar of greed?,
 
Dr. S. Wijeyamohan is well known in conservation circles as someone who has long championed the cause of conservation in the North and the East. Specializing in Wildlife Ecology, Conservation and Management, he is a Senior Lecturer in the Department of Bio-science of the University of Vavuniya. There can be none better than Dr. Wijeyamohan to help us understand the reality, and lift the fog of ignorance of these vastly biodiverse, and increasingly threatened, vitally precious areas of this Nation.
 
The monthly lecture of the WNPS is supported by the Nations Trust Bank. It is open to both members and non-members, ENTRANCE FREE.

Yesterday our Students faced the core event of the European Master in Disaster Medicine Residential Course: the Full Scale Exercise. This large simulation took place in Solbiate Olona (Varese, Italy) where the Italian Army deployed a ROLE 3 field hospital.

In the simulated scenario of a post-conflict unstable peace, a sudden heavy storm hit a festival area where many people were gathered. Our master students did their best to respond to the Mass Casualty Incident and coordinate all the forces that came into play to handle the pressure of an already stressed hospital and to save as many lives as possible.

Huge thanks to the City of Solbiate Olona who hosted us, the 150 medical students who played the role of smart victims and the hundreds professionals and volunteers from firefighters, AREU Lombardia, Italian Red Cross Varese and Novara and many more.

Today in 1973, the Yom Kippur War begins. Lasting until October 25, this conflict began when an Arab Coalition, led by Egypt and Syria, attacked Israel. Following the Third Arab-Israeli War (also known as the Six-Day War) in 1967, Egypt and Syria had hoped to recover lost land that was gained by Israel. In 1972, Egyptian President Anwar Sadat expelled 20,000 Soviet advisors from Egypt, and sought new diplomatic relations with Washington DC, in an effort to obtain future hope of peace with Israel. On October 6, 1973, Egyptian and Syrian forces launched an attack against Israel on Yom Kippur. With the conflict occurring mostly around Golan Heights and the Sinai, Egyptian forces fought to keep control of the Suez Canal, while Israeli soldiers launched a major counteroffensive in Syria. The end result was an Israeli military victory, while Egypt and Syria won certain political gains. Five years later, the Camp David Accords were signed in Washington DC, which brought about a new era of peace between Israel and Egypt. On October 6, 1981, Anwar Sadat was assassinated by Islamic extremists in Cairo. #todayinhistory #history

There was a time when I didn‚Äôt take life stressors seriously. ( okay there are still times I don't, but I am working on it.)

I was doing crossfit 6 days a week, running 40 miles a week and only sleeping about 5hrs a night because I worked a physical job that started at 5:30am and I thought I would just sleep when I was dead. 

And to top it off, I was confused as to why I felt like shit. (LOL) 

It wasn‚Äôt until I took a step back from intense training that I started to realize just how awful I felt. I was tired, irritable, and I wasn‚Äôt even making any progress. It was time for a change. 

Stress is part of being human. 

It is what pushes us to grow and adapt, but if you don‚Äôt recover from it properly, it can start to impact your health/progress. 

You might think ‚Äúif stress is part of being human then why should I worry about it.‚Äù 

Just like with everything else, we need to find a balance with stress. Too much or too little is not a good thing. 

Stressors you need to pay attention to: 
üëâphysical ‚Äî e.g., poor sleep, illness, injury, dehydration, hunger, etc.
üëâmental, or cognitive ‚Äî e.g., information overload, too many decisions, solving difficult problems, etc.
üëâemotional ‚Äî e.g., painful emotions such as guilt, sadness, anger, etc.
üëâsocial ‚Äî e.g., conflict with family and friends, loneliness, discrimination, etc.
üëâexistential, or spiritual ‚Äî e.g., hopelessness, crises of faith or identity, etc.
üëâenvironmental, or what‚Äôs around us ‚Äî e.g., temperature, pollution, noise, safety, etc.

A stressor can be anything that disrupts homeostasis, or our ‚Äústatus quo‚Äù. Stressors can occur in any part of life, and they can affect people differently. 

All of these stressors can impact your progress in different ways. Don‚Äôt brush them off or ignore them. Stay aware of your stress levels and make sure you have healthy ways of coping. 

Drop a üòÖin the comments if you are feeling stressed today! üëá

#stress #stressmanagement #fitness #health #mentalhealth

Ia memastikan akan berusaha sebaik mungkin dalam meneruskan program yang sudah dilaksanakan oleh Nan-Suko terutama dibidang pembangunan infrastruktur dan pelayanan kemasyarakatan. 

Pj Wako berharap, Kota Lubuklinggau yang sudah terkenal dengan Zero Conflict-nya dapat terus dijaga. Jangan sampai terjadi kekisruhan diantara sesama warga di Kota Lubuklinggau.

"Terakhir, saya mengajak, mari selalu tingkatkan silaturahmi dan hubungan baik diantara sesama demi mewujudkan Lubuklinggau sebagai Kota Metropolis Madani,‚Äù imbuhnya.

Our Human-Wildlife Conflict Mitigation Unit based in Hunyari remains dedicated to helping nearby communities safely deter crop-raiding elephants back to the concession. Just this week, around 9 PM, we got a call from a concerned resident in Kihumbu village. Working closely with Village Game Scouts and our partners from TAWA who live in Hunyari, our team swiftly reached the reported location in just fifteen minutes. In less than twenty minutes, they effectively guided a herd of fifteen elephants back into the concession area.

Day 8 of my 21-day #GratitudeOnChain journey: Grateful for @ashna.8ters ü•∞

This is my journey to express gratitude on blockchain in a permanent, immutable way.

I was pregnant with Ashna a quarter into my MBA. @devanandreddy and I were upgraded to a 2-bedroom on the Stanford campus. Before Ashna‚Äôs first bath, we bought half the store‚Äôs detergent to deep-clean. We flew to Pittsburgh for her hair shaving ceremony. We call it ‚Äúour most expensive haircut.‚Äù

Ashna is one of the biggest blessings of our lives. @ariyareddy_ , your turn is coming next, eww

ü•∞ She has impeccable timing. Ashna was born a week before the 2nd year of biz school. One of my must-attend courses was Dr. Burgelman and Andy Grove‚Äôs ‚ÄúStrategy is Action‚Äù. The course allowed us to miss 2 classes. With Dev and mom‚Äôs support, I was back in class two weeks after, missing exactly 2.

ü•∞ She is my calm-factor, my moral compass, she stretches my ability to handle conflict, is an excellent communicator and is always the first to say ‚Äúyes‚Äù.

Of all the decisions I have made, the hardest was her daycare. When I handed Ashna over, tears streaming down my face, the caregiver said, ‚ÄúThe baby will eat, sleep and repeat. She will be fine. You need to figure out if YOU will be fine.‚Äù

Fast forward, as I was stressed about my to-do list, Ashna said, ‚ÄúMom, you have always had so much to do. And you always get it done really well. Chill.‚Äù This has become my go-to phrase. It always works out üòÖ

ü•∞ She stays true to herself

When she was 9-years old, she was asked to write about who inspires her. She wrote: ‚ÄúInspiration coming from within.‚Äù ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è 

She studied at a top STEM high-school, and decided to major in Design. This broke many Asian stereotypes, especially given our STEM household. Dev and I couldn‚Äôt be prouder.

Ashna- Thank you for the gift of motherhood. Thank you for who you are. I am thrilled to express my love and #GratitudeOnChain.

"But sometimes my child just has to get with the program!" 

Who's program are we talking about here? 
Externally imposed structures are usually designed without neurodivergence in mind, and directly conflict with the structures neurodivergent need to regulate themselves.
As parents and caregivers, you are in the difficult position of being responsible for putting in structures to help your autistic child thrive. 

It can be a big change in thinking to realise that the structures, routines and rituals neurodivergent people put in place may actually be serving a helpful purpose.
 
Many people instinctively see these as being bad or symptoms of disorder so then try to train the person out of it or discipline them for doing this. This is quite harmful to neurodivergent people. 

Instead of imposing rigid rules that take away your child's coping strategies, it is better to work collaboratively to first understand why neurodivergent people are doing what they are doing, and then working with them to develop structures that best support their growth and ability to thrive.

For more help with supporting your autistic child, follow the link in bio. 

P.S. We üíú NDIS. 
Ways to claim on the website.

Cheers to another dazzling spin around the sun, as I celebrate my 56th birthday with pride! üéÇüåû 
Blessed that I have made it this far as it‚Äôs a privilege denied to many. 

üé®‚ú® Getting older is underrated and I wish someone would have told me how glorious being a crone can be! It‚Äôs the sleeper hit aspect of the triple goddess.

üéÇ I love getting older!
Aging is akin to possessing a time-traveling magic: I carry within me the 13-year-old's curiosity, the 21-year-old's adventure the 36-year-old's passion, and the 42-year-old's resilience. With each passing year, these portals to the past open wide, allowing me to revisit the moments when I dangled my legs from my Caribbean treehouse or shimmied in a Moroccan restaurant in the Village, NYC. üåÜüíÉ
And what a canvas I've become! Freckles, stretch marks, tattoos, wrinkles, birthmarks, and scars - these are not imperfections; they are the artistic brushstrokes of a life richly lived, a story beautifully told. 
Aging has gifted me a crown of freedom. Gone are the days of unnecessary drama, conflict, or stress. I've mastered the art of serenity, even if you tell me 1+1=5 - in my world, you're absolutely right! ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüéâ
Life's storms, which once left me waiting for the sun, now find me grateful in the eye of the tempest. As I've matured, I've embraced the idea that the storm itself, with all its chaos, is a vital part of the journey. üå™Ô∏è
My days are now spacious, free from the tyranny of multitasking. I relish the present moment, allowing my spirit to move through life's rhythms at its own pace. üßò‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
Growing older has also deepened my compassion for others. I see the threads that weave us together, recognizing that in our shared humanity, we all bear our burdens, chase our dreams, and grapple with inner critics. We are one. üåç‚ù§Ô∏è

ONCE UPON A TIME IN THE WEST (1968)

üìçDistributor :¬†Paramount Pictures
üìçWatch on : Not Available in Indonesia

ùêíùêòùêçùêéùêèùêíùêàùêí:
An epic spaghetti Western film that is set in the Old West town of "Flagstone". As the railroad builders advance through the Arizona desert on their way to the sea,¬†Jill (Claudia Cardinale) arrives with the intention of starting a new life. However she is soon followed by assassin Frank (Henry Fonda) while a mysterious stranger with a harmonica (Charles Bronson) and a bandit Cheyenne (Jason Robards) try to protect her.

ùêåùêò ùêëùêÑùêïùêàùêÑùêñ:
GOAT OF WESTERN CINEMA !!! Oh the maestro strikes again.  Sergio Leone is simply the üêê in this Western cinema. No other filmmakers can make a wild west era film like Sergio Leone. He is simply on his own. Damn iconic, damn good.

Leone knows best how to display conflicts in those cowboys era, how the characters set revenge towards one another, and how they unleash their wraths with style. Backed with another masterpiece composing by Ennio Morricone. There are probably 3-4 amazing scorings here that I can listen & listen again. I can never get enough of them.

Here we follow the conflicts between few opposing parties (just like his other films). From a harmonica man, a serial killer, a widow, and a bandit. Together they form a tale that is worth our time - from discussing business aspect, territorial disputes, childhood memory, and finally revenge business. 

There are many slowmos that made this film greater than it already is, especially that first scene & last scene. Oh damn it was probably my top 5 endings of all time. The way everything unfolds in the end bring me to wonder how he did that. Charles Bronson and Fonda performances even made it even more iconic.

Hats off to one of my top 3 Western films of all time. this film stood up there alongside 'The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly' & 'No Country For Old Men'. Notice 2 of them are coming from Sergio Leone. What a film, what a conflict, and what a conclusion. This film is simply something else.

One of the best of cinema üêê

TYPEONE: Issue 06
Available at www.draw-down.com

The sixth issue of TYPEONE Magazine explores the exciting realm of experimental type, where traditional design conventions are challenged and pushed to the limit. The feature articles identify the many different ways that type can be used to express tones, feelings, cultures, and creativity, and explore the cultural influences that are shaping the experimental type landscape.

Articles include "Trending: #Experimental #type fused with celebrities, streetwear and pop culture," "Tech, type and tools: A conflict of poetry and practicality," and "How to #design custom lettering with Victoria England." Includes contributions from Alice Sherwin, Clarissa Jurumenha, Daniela Retana, Eso Tolson, Harry Bennett, Michela Zoppi, Poppy Thaxter and Rand Al-Hadethi.

Q6-CHAPTER 12

WOULD YOU HAVE FOLLOWED GABRIELLA?

Sorry, I wouldn't. I wasn't convinced by her plan. It would have been better if she had prepared more for what she was about to do. There is no way I would have put my life or the lives of my family in danger for it. 

Blurb:
Declared unfit for active service after the Great War, Richard Hansen feels rudderless and out of place. But when the unthinkable happens, and the shadow of a new conflict looms, he is thrust into enemy territory once again for a final, covert mission.

Devastated and mourning her own catastrophic losses, his wife Emily is alone and adrift in a once-idyllic marriage grown cold and distant. When one day, a surprise visitor comes calling, she is faced with a choice that may grant her the very thing she has always longed for‚Ä¶ or lead her into terrible danger.

As Europe goes to war a second time and Richard and Emily‚Äôs paths are wrenched apart, each must confront the ghosts of their own past, battling forces both seen and unseen as their lifelong love is tested to its limits - by duty, grief, time, and betrayal.

One of the top things I wanted to do in Sarajevo was to go to the top of Trebeviƒá mountain by cable car and explore the old Olympic bobsled track. The cable car station is near the City Hall, although it's up so many steps that you might feel like you've climbed the mountain before you even get to the cable car ü§£ 

The original cable car opened in 1959 and was used for the Winter Olympics in 1984. This stopped running before the war, and was completely destroyed in the conflict. The one you see today is only a few years old. 

On the top of the mountain there are lots of walking and mountain biking trails but the main attractions are the views over Sarajevo and the abandoned Olympic bobsled track. The track saw lots of fighting during the Bosnian war but is still relatively intact, although covered in graffiti. That night when we got back to the hotel I watched footage of it being used for the Olympics - like a lot of things in Sarajevo, it's fascinating to see but mixed with sadness for what happened during the war.

In the last year alone, over seven million people in 58 countries benefitted from our work collectively, through landmine and unexploded ordnance clearance, emergency response, disaster prevention, and peacebuilding.

A military academy in Syria was targeted in an attack, resulting in the tragic deaths of at least 100 individuals. This attack occurred shortly after Syria's defense minister had departed from a graduation ceremony at the academy.

Notably, the attack was one of the most deadly incidents involving a Syrian army facility and marked an unprecedented use of weaponized drones in a nation that has endured 12 years of civil conflict.

Berliner Herbstsalons dieses Wochenende weiter. Wir freuen uns besonders auf das anschlie√üende Q&A in Anwesenheit der Regisseur*innen an allen drei Abenden: 

In ùóîùó£ùóõùóîùó¶ùóúùóî untersucht ùóùùó≤ùóπùó≤ùóªùóÆ ùóùùòÇùóøùó≤≈°ùóÆ die Wiederholung kollektiver Verbrechen und die Konstruktion nationaler Identit√§ten. Das Gorki stellt den Film in einer Doppelvorstellung am Freitag einem Werk von ùóùùó≤ùóÆùóª-ùóüùòÇùó∞ ùóöùóºùó±ùóÆùóøùó± gegen√ºber. 

Unterschiedliche zeitliche Perspektiven auf den Konflikt im ehemaligen Jugoslawien kommen auch am Samstag zusammen: Wir zeigen Filme von ≈†ùóÆùóµùó∂ùóª ≈†ùó∂≈°ùó∂ƒá und ùóöùóºùóøùóÆùóª ùóóùó≤ùòÉùó∂ƒá.

Der Film von ≈Ωùó∂ùòÉùóºùó∑ùó∂ùóª ùó£ùóÆùòÉùóπùóºùòÉùó∂ƒá aus dem Jahr 1967 zeigt die Geschichte eines jungen Vagabunden, der als Saisonarbeiter arbeitet, und gilt als eines der ikonoklastischen Werke der jugoslawischen vague noir ‚Äì am Sonntag im Gorki zu sehen.
