Different temporal perspectives on the conflict in the former Yugoslavia also come together on Saturday: We will show films by ≈†ùóÆùóµùó∂ùóª ≈†ùó∂≈°ùó∂ƒá and and ùóöùóºùóøùóÆùóª ùóóùó≤ùòÉùó∂ƒá.

The film by ≈Ωùó∂ùòÉùóºùó∑ùó∂ùóª ùó£ùóÆùòÉùóπùóºùòÉùó∂ƒá from 1967 tells the story of a young vagabond who works as a seasonal labourer, and is considered one of the iconoclastic works of the Yugoslavian vague noir - on view at Gorki on Sunday.

Summary: ‚û°Ô∏è
Format: Audio (thank you @prhaudio) and physical (thank you for the complimentary copy @duttonbooks) ü´∂üèª
Rating: 4.5/5 ‚≠êÔ∏è 

‚ÄúI secretly love romantic comedies despite what I said earlier about classic films, and I think I was a miserably unhappy person until I met you.‚Äù

Guys, this was so lovely ü•πü•π. My favorite romcom of all time is 50 First Dates and that‚Äôs totally the vibe this book gave me.

Every night Gemma goes to bed she forgets all about Jack, this handsome wonderful man who has been trying to win her heart every single day‚Ä¶ whilst stuck in a time loop. Every night Gemma‚Äôs memories are wiped clean, and every day Jack falls more in love with her and is more determined to break the loop & get her to remember him.

I loved the drama, the family conflict (and resolutions), and the dynamic between Gemma and her best friend Lila. This book has so much heart to it and touched me deeply. I really felt like I could connect and relate to some of the struggles the characters were dealing with, and this book also genuinely made me laugh multiple times. 

I loved the whole sci-fi aspect of this romance and I also really enjoyed the narration. From the first chapter I was hooked. ‚ÄúPlease remember me, Gemma.‚Äù Ugh, my heart. 

This book was just a really good time & stands out from the other romances I‚Äôve read. 

I love a unique romance & this one will definitely stay on my mind for a long time! 

‚ú® Read this if you love: The movie 50 First Dates, The Seven Year Slip by Ashley Poston, Back to the Future, and/or The Do-Over by Lynn Painter ‚ú® 

üí≠ Do you prefer realistic romances, or do you enjoy ones that are more fantastical?

üáÆüá™ ~ üè¥Û†ÅßÛ†Å¢Û†Å•Û†ÅÆÛ†ÅßÛ†Åøüá¨üáß ‚Ä¢ Soldiers of the British Army armed with SA80 assault rifles, and Snatch Land Rover (with improvised armour), it had a 'confidential phone number' on its side ‚Äì in Belfast, Northern Ireland, United Kingdom, c. late 1980s or mid-1990s - The Troubles - 30 years of anti-insurgency operations by the British Armed Forces. 

The Irish republicanism movement ‚¨áÔ∏è‚¨áÔ∏è

__
During the Cold War in Europe - It was following the outbreak of The Troubles in 1966 / August 1969, the Irish republicanism movement had split between the Official Irish Republican Army (Official IRA) and the Provisional Irish Republican Army (IRA) at the beginning of 1970. 

__
Both groups were initially involved in an armed conflict against the British Army, but the Official IRA later moved into mainstream politics after their official ceasefire in 1972, the associated 'Official Sinn F√©in' eventually renamed itself The Workers' Party (active in the Republic of Ireland, and Northern Ireland in the UK). 

__
The Provisional Irish Republican Army, except during brief ceasefires with the British Armed Forces in 1972 and 1975, kept up its campaign of violence for nearly thirty years. It was directed against British soldiers and police and commercial targets (especially businesses) in the 1970s, 1980s, and until early 1998. 

#TheHistoryoftheBritishIsles

Among others, the delegation met with current Security Council members and Permanent Representatives of Switzerland and Ghana, as well as the Assistant Secretary-General for Human Rights, H.E. We wish to thank the delegation for their eager participation and engagement during the past two weeks!

Conflict has forced these people to seek shelter in a disaster zone. 

As fighting rages in neighboring Sudan, hundreds of thousands have fled to parts of South Sudan already struggling to contain alarming rates of extreme hunger with limited resources. Most making this desperate journey are originally from South Sudan but were living as refugees across the border when war broke out. 

Returning to the country they fled years ago is not a straightforward affair. Some families arrive at crowded transit centers with children who are fighting for their lives due to severe malnutrition. They then have to make multi-day treks by boat and overland transport just to reach temporary shelters. 

To help people reeling from the impact of these overlapping crises, we‚Äôre helping the UN @worldfoodprogramme deliver emergency food assistance and administer treatment for malnutrition at transit centers and locations where returnees finally arrive. With support from @usaid and other donors, the UN agency has already reached 265,000 vulnerable people with life-saving aid, with more help on the way.

üì∑: WFP

#sudan #southsudan #humanitarian #humanitarianaid #usaidsaveslives #africa #crisis #foodaid @usaidpower

A fine and scarce 1918 Great War Sopwith Camel fighter ace‚Äôs Distinguished Flying Cross and bar awarded to Captain Solomon Clifford Joseph of the Royal Naval Air Service and Royal Air Force - who was the highest scoring Jewish ace of the Great War is to be included in a sale of Orders, Decorations, Medals and Militaria at Noonans Mayfair on Wednesday, October 11, 2023.  Not only was Captain Joseph the highest scoring Jewish Ace of the Great War; he was the only Ace of the conflict to hail from Birmingham.‚Å†
‚Å†
As Mark Quayle, Medal Specialist and Associate Director of Noonans commented: ‚ÄúJoseph was a ‚Äúgung-ho‚Äù pilot, whose aggressive flying style and skill accounted for at least 13 aerial victories over the Western Front between May - October 1918. He was no stranger to taking risks, and was wounded in aerial combat, and nearly shot down on many occasions.‚Äù ‚Å†
#medals #fighterace #sopwithcamel #RAF #RNAS #greatwar #jewishfighterace #BirminghamFlighterAce #WW1‚Å†

Juma is just 11 years old, but he has already lost an eye and a hand to a grenade.

When he came to our hospital in Khartoum, he was screaming in fear. A piece of chocolate was the only thing that could calm him down.

Juma‚Äôs parents are missing, most likely from the ongoing conflict in the country.

Now, he is doing better. His other eye ‚Äì which had also been hit ‚Äì is safe. ‚ÄúJuma is lively again,‚Äù Gina, Medical Coordinator, tells us. ‚ÄúHe even went out to the garden yesterday to eat.‚Äù

Within a city engulfed in fighting, our Centre for Emergency and Trauma Surgery provides care for civilian victims of the war.

We are not abandoning Sudan.

The history of Rwanda is painful to process- Prior to the colonial era, Tutsis generally occupied the higher strata in the social system and the Hutus the lower. However, social mobility was possible, a Hutu who acquired a large number of cattle or other wealth could be assimilated into the Tutsi group and impoverished Tutsi would be regarded as Hutu. A clan system also functioned, with the Tutsi clan known as the Nyinginya being the most powerful. Throughout the 1800s, the Nyingiya expanded their influence by conquest and by offering protection in return for tribute.

By 1962, when Rwanda gained independence, 120,000 people, primarily Tutsis, had taken refuge in neighboring states to escape the violence which had accompanied the gradual coming into power of the Hutu community.

A new cycle of ethnic conflict and violence continued after independence. Tutsi refugees in Tanzania and Zaire seeking to regain their former positions in Rwanda began organizing and staging attacks on Hutu targets and the Hutu government.
The attacks were one of the factors leading to the war between Rwanda and the Democratic Republic of Congo that took place in 1996. Former Rwandan forces continue to operate in the DRC alongside Congolese militia and other armed groups. They continue to target civilian populations and cause deaths, injury and harm. On 6 April 1994, the deaths of the Presidents of Burundi and Rwanda in a plane crash caused by a rocket attack, ignited several weeks of intense and systematic massacres. The killings - more than one million people are estimated to have perished - shocked the international community and were clearly acts of genocide. An estimated 150,000 to 250,000 women were also raped. Members of the presidential guard started killing Tutsi civilians in a section of Kigali near the airport. Less than half an hour after the plane crash, roadblocks manned by Hutu militiamen often assisted by gendarmerie (paramilitary police) or military personnel were set up to identify Tutsis

IN FIELDS OF WORDS üé•

This film explores the profound connection between the fates of Syria and Lebanon through a dialogue with Samar Yazbek, a prominent Syrian writer and activist living in exile in Paris. Over eight years, the film delves into the question of whether cinema and literature can make a difference in the face of war and what it means to bear witness as a writer. Instead of focusing on the spectacle of war, the film uses a layered approach, combining various elements like images, sounds, music, and text to reveal the inner world of the writer. As the conflict intensifies, the film grapples with the dilemma of whether to speak out or remain silent. The film ultimately presents a poignant and politically relevant testimony of our troubled times through the dialogue between two women artists.

Arab Cinema Week is organized in partnership with Safar Film Festival @safarfilmfestival 

Get your tickets now through our link in bio. Season pass tickets are also available. 

#followusintothedark #fortheloveoffilm #arabcinemaweek

I just love this piece of art so I am sharing :Strat√©gie en chambre
1999
painted plaster, plastic, and paper
M+ Sigg Collection, Hong Kong. By donation
Wang Du was in Paris when the war in Kosovo broke out in 1998. Reading Western European newspapers as well as coverage from outlets in Yugoslavia, he noticed that different narratives about the war were being told. Wang began to collect daily reports and analyses, creating an assemblage of papers with plastic toy tanks, ships, and fighter jets. Busts of American president Bill Clinton and Russian president Boris Yeltsin appear embedded within this carefully landscaped battlefield. The work's title, which translates from French as 'armchair strategy', describes the position of a distant observer whose idle talk is based entirely on media reportage. Wang creates a war zone in which alternate truths engage in conflict. #M+ #M+museum #hongkong #art #news #fakenews #lifeevents #media #journalism #ronagam

IREX Community Solutions Program 2024/2025 for Community youth leaders (Fully Funded to the United States)
 
Application Deadline: November 1, 2023  https://bit.ly/3rEvpiu

The Community Solutions Program (CSP) is a year-long professional leadership development program for established community leaders working to improve their communities by addressing issues related to the democracy and human rights, environment, peace and conflict resolution, and women and gender. CSP includes a four-month hands-on U.S. practicum, personalized leadership coaching and training through a graduate level leadership curriculum, and a six-month follow-on community project fellows implement in their home country. 

Requirements

You are between the ages of 26 and 39 as of January 1, 2024

You are a citizen of one of the eligible countries listed below

You are living and working in your home country

Individuals with refugee status working on behalf of their home community may be given special consideration

You have at least two years of experience working on community development, either as a full-time or part-time employee or volunteer

Benefits

The program covers the cost of most expenses associated with:

J-1 visa support

Round-trip travel from participants‚Äô home city to the U.S.

Monthly allowance to cover housing, meals, and other living expenses while in the U.S. 

Accident and sickness health coverage

Accessibility accommodations, such as ADA accessible rooms for in-person training, software such as JAWS, and community assistance and community training

As the new semester starts, PWSC's team of resident assistants (RAs) - Issac Stevens, Mahali Santa Ana, and Lydia Worrall-Edie - along with Dr. Dale Jones, the residence life coordinator and housing manager, are working diligently to build a vibrant and supportive community on our college campus.

Lydia shared that they have created a comprehensive plan to bring the community closer, including engaging activities. They organized movie nights and homemade ice cream gatherings to strengthen their bond. Moreover, they've struck a balance by incorporating productivity-enhancing events like study nights alongside fun-filled adventures such as a Halloween-themed spooky hike.

When asked about their training as RAs, they emphasized the diverse range of skills they have acquired, including proficiency in Title IX and conflict resolution. Mahali stressed the importance of gaining hands-on experience and understanding their unique student demographic and the flow of events to ensure their success as RAs. Dale, addressing the challenge of a growing student body and a consistent number of RAs, stresses the importance of inclusivity and reaching out to various student groups.

They aim to ensure everyone feels part of this vibrant campus community by being aware, proactive, and mindful of individual needs. With a positive outlook and a new wave of enthusiastic students, this team is well on its way to creating a thriving and welcoming college environment.
Issac expressed, "My goal is to make this year as memorable as possible for all students. I enjoy working with Mahali and Lydia to make that possible."
#collegecommunity #pwsc #collegelifeüòç

For the second year in a row, we have been providing vocational training opportunities for conflict-affected women in Barda, Aghjabadi and Tartar.
60 women successfully completed "Using Microsoft Office programmes" üíªcourse, which we organized together with Barda Vocational Lyceum for members of the Women's Resource Centers located in 3 regions. The course covered Microsoft Word, Excel, and Power Point programmes.

At the next stage, women will master their skills in accounting. 60 women are expected to complete the #vocational course on accounting.

These vocational courses are being organized as part of the ‚ÄúEmpowering and creating equal opportunities for vulnerable, conflict-affected women in Azerbaijan to overcome barriers towards greater economic and social participation (ECEO)‚Äù project implemented by UNDP and SCFWCA with the financial support of the UK Government.

New @unicef and Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre research found that at least 43 million children have been displaced by extreme weather in the last six years. This is a tragic injustice.

Climate displacement is particularly traumatic for children ‚Äì they are far more exposed to risk than adults, and when displaced, they lose access to critical education, health services, and community.

This image is of Dadaab refugee camp, which houses refugees fleeing conflict and climate-induced drought in Somalia. The analysis found the greatest proportion of child displacements were in both small-island states and here, in the Horn of Africa.

Children are disproportionately impacted by the #ClimateCrisis, yet most climate policy fails to consider them.

Current legal protections for climate refugees are not adequate. Leaders must come to an international agreement to protect all climate refugees, particularly children. The voices of young people must also be heard and included in the policy-making process.

#ClimateRefugees #ClimateActionNow

It‚Äôs been one year since we started our ‚ÄòEducation for Every Child Today (EFECT)‚Äô project, implemented in partnership with @educationaboveall_eaa. This ambitious project aims to make a lasting impact by placing and retaining 96,000 primary school-aged children in education across Sierra Leone, Liberia and Nigeria by 2026 ‚Äì and we‚Äôve been busy! 

Results from our first year include:
ü§ùüèø Engaging 24,000 caregivers to promote the benefits of schooling & highlight their children‚Äôs right to education
üìö Enrolling more than 16,500 out-of-school children, 50% of which are girls, in quality primary education
‚úèÔ∏è Establishing 50 temporary learning centres for children affected by conflict in Nigeria 
üèóÔ∏è Constructing 75 new classrooms in Sierra Leone and 15 classrooms in Liberia

Read more in our blog ‚ÄòEffecting Change: Our One Year Results.' Link in bio üîó

Today, we celebrate the 20th anniversary of our global conflict tracker and early warning tool #CrisisWatch üéâ

‚ùó CrisisWatch is a vital tool for anyone trying to stay abreast of and understand the world‚Äôs shifting conflict landscape.

üóì It provides monthly summaries of political and security developments in over 70 conflicts, crises and vulnerable countries.

üåé When it was created in September 2003, CrisisWatch‚Äôs first early warning bulletin covered about 50 situations of conflict. Today, CrisisWatch covers about 70 conflicts and also monitors major developments in another 40-50 situations.

üóÑ Our database, which contains 18k entries dating all the way back to 2003, reflects our dedication to early warning work and also serves as a valuable source of historical analysis.

We are also proud to announce that we have revamped CrisisWatch to offer greater clarity on what we track and how we make our qualitative assessments.

üÜï Every CrisisWatch entry now explores conflict trends through the following features:

‚úÖ Summary of key political and security developments in an opening bolded line for each conflict, w/ a transparent analysis of how we assessed the situation.

‚úÖ Our analysis is broken down into multiple thematic issues; with a short sentence in italics to introduce each theme.

üó∫ We have also revamped our interactive map with new vibrant colours that help users navigate global conflict situations quickly and easily.

üîé These changes offer readers greater visibility on the local, regional and global dynamics that shape conflicts, including some that may be ‚Äúunder the radar‚Äù.

Check out CrisisWatch's 242nd edition published today through the üîó in bio.

In October 2020, the Human Rights Council recognized the crucial role of women in the prevention and resolution of conflicts and in peacebuilding and confidence-building. Women are disproportionately affected during conflict yet have little opportunity to participate as equal stakeholders in post-conflict rebuilding. 

In 2020, only 28.6% of total peace agreements had gender provisions included in them. As a women-led grassroots organization, the Centre for Women and Girls in Manipur is committed to gender equity, child rights, peace processes & livelihoods by investing in girl leadership.

This International Give to Women and Girls Day - October 11, stand up for the rights and futures of women and girls served by Shadhika‚Äôs newest partner @CWG.manipur

Blurb 
A consummate warrior and brilliant strategist, Pino is a young Native American woman who must fight against fierce invaders to save her tribe ‚Äî and spirit ‚Äî from annihilation in precolonial southern New England.

The strange tale of sisterhood begins on the stormy spring morning her tribe faces imminent attack by a contingent of the mighty Pagassett Nation, infamous for destroying small tribes in its quest for land and power. Pino knows this is the moment she‚Äôs been waiting for, a chance to save her people and maybe ‚Äîmaybe ‚Äî redeem herself for failing to rescue her beloved sister, murdered ten summers ago.

Aided by her best warrior and forbidden love, Tow, and key tribal leaders who witness Pino‚Äôs gift for camouflage, she clandestinely influences strategy in the short, but wildly intense conflict. She soon discovers her real opposition is Meesha, a beautiful near-slave taken in by the invading tribe when just a girl. By learning how the other operates, the women form an intimate, almost magical sisterhood in their internal fight to free their inner demons.

"The Eternal Love Story" by Aatmn Parmar is a unique and thought-provoking exploration of spiritual growth and the transformative power of love. This book takes readers on a journey that seamlessly blends personal and spiritual development with a captivating narrative.

At the heart of the story are Sarah, a soul in search of a Guru, and a young Indian entrepreneur who becomes the catalyst for her inner transformation. Author's storytelling skillfully weaves together their experiences, making it a compelling and engaging read.

One of the strengths of this book is its ability to convey complex spiritual concepts in an accessible and relatable manner. Through the characters' journeys, readers are invited to contemplate the fusion of material and spiritual aspects of life, and the idea of discovering the "Guru Within" is both inspiring and enlightening.

The characters are well-developed, and their personal growth and evolution throughout the story are portrayed with depth and authenticity. Sarah's journey from disillusionment to self-realization, guided by her interactions with the Indian entrepreneur, is a central theme that resonates with readers on multiple levels.

"The Eternal Love Story" successfully navigates the balance between spirituality and the material world, offering readers a fresh perspective on how these two aspects can complement each other rather than being in conflict. The book encourages readers to embrace life's challenges and experiences as opportunities for growth and self-discovery.

Aatmn Parmar's writing style is engaging and immersive, making it easy for readers to become emotionally invested in the characters and their journeys. The narrative is filled with moments of insight and wisdom, making it a valuable read for spiritual seekers and those looking to deepen their understanding of the human experience.

Parenting, whether it‚Äôs a shared journey or a solo expedition, is a complex dance of influences shaping our children‚Äôs behavior and emotional landscape.

For those navigating this path with a partner, the dynamics between caregivers become a silent yet potent teacher. Every interaction, every disagreement, and every tender moment is a lesson absorbed by young, impressionable minds.

üß† Children are deep observers, internalizing the nuances of love, conflict, and communication unfolding before them. It‚Äôs not about crafting a facade of perfection but fostering an environment of awareness, growth, and authenticity.

üìö Studies (Cummings & Davies, 1994) highlight the profound impact of parental interactions on a child‚Äôs emotional and behavioral fabric. It‚Äôs an unspoken curriculum, weaving foundational lessons on relationships, respect, and emotional navigation.

üå± Whether we‚Äôre co-parenting or steering the ship alone, an introspective gaze into our actions and interactions can unveil opportunities to nurture emotionally intelligent, resilient children.

üí≠ Reflective moment: What‚Äôs one thing you hope your child learns from observing your relationships? Share your thoughts and aspirations in the comments.

Akram and Joumana are Meadow Heights residents who came to Australia as a result of conflict and persecution in Syria and have made such a positive contribution to our community, including through organisations like Zenobia Association. 

They also operate a fantastic business, Trio Pastry Sweets And Nuts, on Lygon St Carlton. 

It received such a great review in today‚Äôs Herald Sun, I had to pop in to collect some delicious Syrian sweets for the office on the way back to Greenvale from Parliament!

In this particular region of Ethiopia, conflict is common. Ethnic conflict destabilizes the peace, and religious groups often find themselves at odds. That was what pastor Eliso*, coordinator of the local church, wanted to find a solution for. He partnered with Open Doors and thanks to your support, the funds were provided to dig a new well on the grounds of the church compound. 
 
This addressed two issues: First, clean water isn't easy to come by for this community. This new water pump is solar powered and provides clean water to approximately 1000 households today. Second, it became a place where people with differences could come and congregate. Both Muslims and Christians use the well, and where there has previously been hostility Eliso sees friendship. One visitor to the compound said "There is no pressure on us when we come to fetch water. We are not asked for any payment. What we have is respect and love now. We even enjoy coffee together in their compound."
 
Praise God for the peacemakers in Ethiopia!
 
*pseudonym used

James Jabbar Williams, Jr., 18, of Saint Helena Island, SC is in custody and charged with attempted murder and possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime.

Williams‚Äô charges stem from a shooting at Tiger Express, 375 Sea Island Parkway, Lady‚Äôs Island, SC that left a 50-year-old man suffering from a non-life-threatening gunshot wound.

On October 5, 2023, at approximately 4:15 p.m., Sheriff‚Äôs deputies were dispatched to the Tiger Express for a gunshot victim.  When they arrived, they found the man suffering from a gunshot wound to his thigh. 

Deputies learned that a conflict between the victim and Williams began while both were driving on Sea Island Parkway and one cut the other off in traffic.

Both vehicles pulled into the Tiger Express gas station where a verbal argument ensued.  The argument then escalated to Williams shooting the victim.

Deputies quickly identified Williams as the person responsible for the shooting.  He was located on Dulamo Road on Saint Helena Island shortly after 5:00 p.m. where he was detained.  As the investigation progressed, Williams was arrested and charged.

Williams is incarcerated at the Beaufort County Detention Center.

Matters pertaining to education transformation and gun violence were among the areas discussed during a courtesy call between Prime Minister Mia Amor Mottley and non-resident Apostolic Nuncio of the Holy See, The Most Reverend Santiago de Wit Guzm√°n.

During the meeting at Government Headquarters recently, Prime Minister Mottley informed The Most Reverend de Wit Guzm√°n, who is also Archbishop of Gabala, and his team, about Government‚Äôs proposed education transformation.

She stressed that all students must have equal opportunities to utilise their talents under a more balanced system.

‚ÄúThe last major reform in education in this country was premised on the 1940s English legislation, which said ‚Ä¶ ‚Äòlet us focus on the top 30 to 40 per cent but let us make sure that the next 60 to 70 per cent are manageable‚Äô, which was the colonial approach. ¬†

‚ÄúRegrettably, we have not broken the chains and the mould of that, so that we see, hear, and create opportunities for each and every child.¬† We have started, but we‚Äôre not where we want to be. Therefore, we need to make a greater resolve in order to ensure that each child can have the best possible future according to their talents,‚Äù Ms. Mottley stated.

She also expressed her deep concern about gun violence and abuse across the region, pointing out that it was necessary to find ways to encourage people to solve conflict, adding ‚Äúit has to be a whole of nation approach, whole-of-region approach, and a whole-of-world approach to tackling this issue‚Äù.

Meanwhile, the non-resident Apostolic Nuncio proffered the view that valuing the lives of individuals and strengthening the family unit could be used as tools to address violence.

‚ÄúI think families are very important and strengthening this institution should be a real goal‚Ä¶. Love, trust, confidence, and understanding that we can rely on one another and trust each other and the fact that we can build something together is very, very powerful. We can also further educate the younger generation about the importance of the family unit,‚Äù he said. The two officials also discussed the ongoing crisis in Haiti.

The Most Reverend de Wit Guzm√°n is based in Trinidad.

üì∏ J. Bishop/BGIS

Welcome to Issue 138 of The Continent

Images of the Chagos Islands, which are illegally occupied by Britain, are rare. Images of Chagos from the perspective of Chagossians themselves are even rarer. They were brutally evicted from their land in 1973, and have been denied the right to return ever since. That‚Äôs what makes our cover image, a painting of Chagos by the Chagossian artist Modeste Alexis, all the more special. His mother Charlesia Alexis, was a tireless campaigner for the right of Chagossians to return home. That struggle is reaching its culmination, with Britain ‚Äì after being embarrassed in international courts ‚Äì currently negotiating the terms of a handover with Mauritius. But the proposed terms of this deal have divided the tight-knit, long-suffering Chagossian community.

INSIDE
In Egypt, let them eat speeches; Somalia‚Äôs fraught war on terror; and the conflict undermining Somaliland‚Äôs standing. Plus, in this week‚Äôs photo essay, The Continent goes on the road with Salim Ahmed.

We will speak about the difference between being in the ring with a referee and being involved in true anti social or a social violence. Listen in to this episode to learn how to change your mindset and perspective through discussion and actual drills, and how to spot pre-attack indicators to avoid violence.

Africa's growth projection is either on an upward to downward trend, depending on who you ask and when.

However, throughout the year, the idea of Africa experiencing an economic downward spiral, albiet marginally, has been consistent. Be it the World Bank or the IMF, the projection on Africa's economic figures has been on the declining side.

According to the World Bank's September Africa Pulse report, economic activity in Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA) is predicted to have further slowed from 3.6 percent in 2022 to 2.5 percent in 2023, which is a downward revision of 0.6 percentage points from the prediction in the report's April 2023 edition.

The report notes that 28 of the 48 nations in Sub-Saharan Africa have had their growth projections for 2023 revised downward. Notably, the growth prediction for Sudan has been lowered downward by 12.5 percentage points due to the harm done to the nation's industrial foundation, as well as its educational and medical infrastructure, by the armed conflict that began there in April 2023.

With that said, the projected trend begs the question of what factors are responsible for the World Bank‚Äôs assessment. Some of the factors that have contributed to the downward trend include monetary and fiscal policy tightness in response to high inflation and fiscal unsustainability, high risk of debt distress, structural constraints such as energy and transportation bottlenecks, and rising conflict and violence manifested in a series of events such as coup d‚Äô√©tats, protests, and heightened social unrest across Sub-Saharan African countries

Recent research on global growth phases suggests that Sub-Saharan Africa consistently has lower rates of poverty that are sensitive to economic expansion than other areas.

This lower elasticity appears to be caused by a weaker relationship between GDP and household consumption growth in Sub-Saharan Africa, which suggests that African countries need to experience higher growth per capita to match improvements in average living standards experienced by households in other regions.

‚ÄúAre you building the best version of the same that you‚Äôve seen before? Or are you in deep contemplation with yourself to ask how to build a better world? Because that‚Äôs what we need the designers, architects and planners for." -Colette Pichon Battle, Taproot Earth

Monday afternoon was turned upside down this week when Dr. Andrea Dutton and Colette Pichon Battle delivered electrifying lectures that covered the physics of sea level rise and grounded our perspectives in the social and political histories of climate change.

Designing for the future requires a complete understanding of the histories and systems, both scientific and political, that have led to where we find ourselves today. Otherwise, we risk simply adding conflict to issues like displacement, job insecurity and urban heat, among others.

This is an Envision Resilience Speaker Series lecture you won‚Äôt want to miss. Tune in to the recording and join the call to imagine and design a more just world for all. Link in our bio.

*ùóßùó™* If I‚Äôm being completely honest with myself, the only thing that‚Äôs kept me alive since high school is the fact that I‚Äôm scared of what would happen to my soul in the afterlife if I killed myself.

I don‚Äôt talk a lot about my mental health struggles, but sometimes I get a nudge to share from the deepest depths of my heart because my Inner Muse compels me to.

Today I want to share how my depression caused me to fail freshman year, lose out on one of my favorite jobs in early adulthood, and recently has shifted my work-life dramatically. 

Let‚Äôs start at the beginning.

In high school, the first waves of depression arose around 14 as I found myself floating between the cliques, not sure where I belonged or why I felt so different.

I was struggling with inner conflict that came from hiding my sexual identity.

I didn‚Äôt have any deep friendships, I was the black sheep of my family, and my neurodivergence made it hard to sit still and focus. I was failing multiple classes, and at one point I literally gave up. 

It was a perfect storm for a teenager to come to the conclusion that I‚Äôd probably be better off dead.

No one would really miss me, or so I thought.

I even got as far as making a plan to end it all with a full bottle of Adderall but a family friend actually ended up killing himself before I got the chance to off myself.

I saw how deeply his death affected me and the people around me.

It was enough for me to reconsider taking my own life and I somehow found the strength to push through high school- this was when I learned how to shape-shift and push my feelings down. 

It worked for a time until I eventually graduated and found some relief by learning to be more authentic.

I thought that would be the end of my depression, but I was not so fortunate.

Fast forward to 2016-17, I was working at a high school as an educational assistant for the Hawaii Department of Education.

To keep a long story short, I was having severe health issues that left me overwhelmed, exhausted, and glued to my bed- even when I knew I had to go out, ‚Äúbe an adult,‚Äù to take care of myself.

"Consequential Urges" written by Author Bruno Beaches

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê

"Consequential Urges" by Bruno Beaches delves into the turbulent world of Pablo, a man grappling with the weight of profound loss. Frustration and the pull toward violence lead Pablo to seek guidance from a psychologist in an attempt to regain control over his actions. However, the trajectory of his life takes an unforeseen turn, propelling him into a whirlpool of unintended consequences where his very existence hangs in the balance.

The narrative is a rollercoaster of emotions, effortlessly drawing readers into Pablo's tumultuous journey. The characters are skillfully portrayed, and the plot twists maintain an element of suspense, ensuring readers remain engaged and guessing throughout. The story provides a window into the human struggle, showcasing how even the seemingly unshakable can be pushed to their limits.

Consequential Urges tackles themes of loss, inner conflict, and the unpredictable aftermath of our choices. Bruno Beaches weaves a compelling narrative that serves as both a gripping thriller and a mirror to life's intricacies. This book challenges readers to reflect on the intricate nature of existence and the pivotal role our decisions play. For enthusiasts of thrillers that stir emotions and prompt introspection, this book is a must-read.

Florian, Colombia ~ Part I
The story of a country, its conflict, and a new chapter. 

The U.S. State Department‚Äôs current travel advisory for Colombia is at level 3. ‚ÄúReconsider travel due to¬†crime¬†and¬†terrorism. Exercise increased caution due to¬†civil unrest¬†and¬†kidnapping‚Äù. The Colombian conflict began in the mid 1940‚Äôs during the period known as La Violencia. Control of the land has undoubtedly been the primary factor for a war that is now considered the longest ongoing armed conflict in Latin America. The fighting primarily took place in the countryside, isolating entire communities and making access to many places impossible. But things have been slowly shifting since the mid 2000‚Äôs, giving way to a new era of exploration in one of the most biodiverse countries in the world. At the forefront of this movement is a small group of climbers that have dedicated the past decade to advancing the country‚Äôs standard of sport climbing in a place known as The Land of Open Windows. 

The town of Florian boasts a stunning view of a steep mountain rock face where a cascading waterfall drops hundreds of meters to the valley below from a cave called Las Ventanas de Tisquizoque. This ancient cave is one of four established climbing areas in Florian with the highest concentration of hard routes ranging up to 5.13+. The high-quality limestone mixed with the steepness of the routes and the three-dimensional feel of the movements make the climbing a truly joyful experience. Filled with stalactites, the river carving through the mountain, and the Andean jungle view from inside the cave makes the entire setting feel surreal. Not to mention the perceived remoteness that makes one feel like being on an expedition to some far-off corner of the world. 

(Written originally for Outdoor Retailer Magazine but never published because the magazine was discontinued last year. Anyone interested?)

In the last year and a half, The Sweaty Penguin has done 13 in-depth stories on carbon bombs: oil and gas projects with the potential to emit over 1 billion tons of carbon dioxide from start to finish. There are many common threads between these mega-projects, from economic inefficiency to environmental destruction, but injustice and conflict seem to come up routinely as well.

But the other commonality: the communities around these projects all present cause for hope. In February, I traveled to Israel curious to learn more about their Leviathan Gas Field, but leaving having learned about a slew of emerging clean tech developments. 

Check out my reflection on this experience at www.thesweatypenguin.com, and check out our many carbon bomb episodes to learn about these important issues and exciting solutions!

"I am very proud of the Merck Foundation "Educating Linda Program", launched 'Educating Linda' in 2019 to help young girls who are unprivileged but brilliant to continue their education. The spirit of the program is to provide an opportunity for such girls to pursue their dreams and reach their potential through access to education. It has been seen that many girls drop out of school due to a lack of necessities such as fees and uniforms. 

The Merck Foundation strongly believes that education is one of the most critical areas of women's empowerment. It is also an area that represents some of the distinct examples of discrimination women suffer. As evident in UNICEF‚Äôs declaration that in Africa, among children not attending school there are twice as many girls as boys, and among illiterate adults there are twice as many women as men. Girls‚Äô education is not a luxury.

Studies show that, in areas where there is high poverty and decades of conflict, girls face enormous challenges that limit their ability to get the education they deserve.

When Girls are educated, their countries become more powerful, stronger & prosperous. There is a need for more support as there are many brilliant girls who are struggling financially and socially to meet their educational needs.

Merck Foundation started ‚ÄúEducating Linda‚Äù, a pan-African program that is tailored for each country to contribute to the future of young African girls who are brilliant but underprivileged. The spirit of the project is to provide an opportunity for such girls to pursue their dreams and reach their potential through access to education.

Merck Foundation Educating Linda program has supported the education of 1000‚Äôs of the high performing girls from various countries like Burundi, CAR, DRC, Ghana, The Gambia, Liberia, Malawi, Namibia, Niger, Nigeria, and Zambia by providing scholarships and grants that can cover school fees, school uniforms and other essentials including notebooks, pens, and mathematical instruments, so they can continue their education."

Senator, Dr. Rasha Kelej
Merck Foundation CEO
President of "More Than a Mother" Campaign

Disclaimer, not for the faint of heart: 
My ex of 7yrs was ex Marines/SBS/Private Security (aka merc) & the one question everyone would always ask him was "what was it like to take a life?", as a trained and licensed to kill professional most of the time he just answered, "it didnt feel real because these days you are shooting at a little black dot in the distance". Unless it was a covert op and they then had to go and clear it up afterwards or dig a mass grave,  a lot of the time it wasnt close up war fare so he said didnt really feel real (dont get me wrong once he left he then had to deal the reality of what he had been ordered to do, hence this incredible, intelligent, funny amazing  young man is no longer with us and took his own life. Bear with me, there's a reason to this story.  So the last close up war we had was the Falklands War, 256 British soldiers were killed during that conflict, and since then 264 veterans have committed suicide. Because it was close up war fare and fighting and the soldiers were seeing their mates being blown up, body parts flying, the trauma this caused and PTSD left these poor veterans unable to live with themselves....one of the times I saw my ex lose it I woke up to see him holding a machete with blood dripping off it and shouting something that I am not going to put on here and I was terrified he had hurt  himself and then the pain hit and I realised he had slashed me with the machete whilst I was asleep, he was moritified and couldnt believe he could do something like, after all the terrible things he had to do and see, cutting me with a blade left him traumatised.  The point of this story is how have we got to a society where people are capable of sticking a knife in someone that can actually kill a person, this is on a whole other level, in America people talk about gun crime and of course its horrific, but again its at a distance, push of a button, pull of a trigger, a drive by and gone, but knife crime, how did we get here? How have we got to a society that people are capable of stabbing people to death? We cannot ignore this any longer. We must unite & fight! Hope you join us there this Sunday 2pm

Thank you to #PASenate Veterans Affairs & Emergency Preparedness Chair, Senator Doug Mastriano, for hosting a ceremony to remember and recognize the heroic sacrifices made by U.S. military men and women during Operation Enduring Freedom. 
Operation Enduring Freedom was the U.S. led military response to the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001.

Oct. 7, 2001, less than one month after the attacks of 9/11, Operation Enduring Freedom signaled the start of the Global War on Terror. 

The conflict would last 13 years, during which the Pennsylvania National Guard mobilized and deployed over 4,200 airmen and 4,470 soldiers. 10 PA National Guard members were killed during this time. 

Together, we recognized the anniversary of the operation, its significance, and its effect on so many Pennsylvania veteran‚Äôs lives and their families.

Facilitators Sought for MCC‚Äôs Workforce Excellence Series 

MOHAVE COUNTY ‚Äì Mohave Community College‚Äôs Workforce Excellence Series is helping businesses and individuals polish skills that promote success in their dealings with customers and community members. The growing popularity of the program now yields another opportunity for involvement, as course facilitators are currently being sought to help propel Mohave County‚Äôs workforce to the next level of service and success. 

Instructors are needed for courses including Manager and Supervisor, Leadership, Communication, Conflict Management and Resolution, Team Performance and Customer Service. Many of these classes focus on workforce fundamentals, such as setting direction for employees, understanding customers and how to manage arising or ongoing conflicts at work. 

As the MCC series is partnering with ARIZONA@WORK to offer tuition coverage for unemployed and underemployed residents of the region, spots are filling up fast. Instructors, working a paid, part-time position at 19.5 hours a week, are now needed for day, evening and weekend classes. 

While many institutions require employees to fit into a rigid schedule, MCC takes a more realistic approach. Lori Gunnette, Associate Dean, Career Training, Professional Development and Community Education, knows that most people have full schedules throughout the day. 

That‚Äôs why the College makes it a point to work with prospective facilitators and their schedules. Vacations, seasonal preferences and more are all taken into consideration during the planning process. 

‚ÄúIf you have a high school diploma or GED, and professional business and industry experience or training in the Workforce Excellence topic areas, we want you to teach for us,‚Äù said Gunnette. ‚ÄúWe are looking for individuals who are passionate about elevating Mohave County's workforce by sharing their professional expertise and industry knowledge.‚Äù 

Read more at mohave.edu/mohavewire

In 2017, I discovered the Resonating Relationship Guide, a beautiful tool created by Discover Healing, which I eagerly shared with my cherished clients. This guide delves into the profound essence of your core love beliefs, explores the lingering traumas from past relationships, and gently guides you through understanding how past experiences may have shaped your reactions and responses in your current love connections.

Fast forward to 2022, and my journey took me to explore the fascinating realms of light scores and shared energies, the unseen threads that weave through our relationships. Inspired by this newfound knowledge, I introduced an Emergency 24-hour session designed specifically for couples facing seemingly insurmountable challenges. The results were nothing short of miraculous, as numerous couples shared heartfelt testimonials about how their partners transformed overnight, leaving them awestruck by the rapidity of their healing and reconciliation.

- Energetic Cord Cutting: Release ties and vows that no longer serve your current relationship, allowing for growth and renewal.

This is a sweet contemporary/historical fantasy mash-up. After her personal and professional life falls apart, Helene escapes to Alaska to start fresh. There she runs into a man who shouldn‚Äôt exist; her imaginary friend, her ideal man who she‚Äôs been writing vignettes about since childhood. While Sebastian initially brushes her off, when they‚Äôre snowed in, he shares the truth; he and Helene are connected to the greatest love story of all time, spanning decades. As the truth sinks in, Helene must decide what she‚Äôs willing to risk for a chance at the type of love she‚Äôs always dreamed of. This book took my a while to get into; the first 50 or so pages really dragged; I think it‚Äôs because there was a lot of telling; all their characters and their surroundings were described in a minute detail, in a way that distracted me from getting into the overall story. Once the tale started to get going, however, I really enjoyed it. The split point of view and flashbacks were really effective, and got you invested in the true breadth of their love story. Helene was really relatable as a main character, I‚Äôve definitely had some of the same worries and insecurities that she dealt with at this stage of life. The final conflict felt a little unbelievable, but I liked the open ended, hopefulness of the ending. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve loved you again and again, across lifetimes. Our story defies reason and science and everything we‚Äôre taught to know about the world, but it is possible. And I think, perhaps, you know it too.‚Äù #virshreads2023 #virshreads #currentlyreading #bookstagrams #bookstagram #bookstagrammers #bookstagrammer #octoberreads #booklover #girlswhoread #book #bookish #supportyourlocallibrary #bookrecommendations #booksbooksandmorebooks #thehundredlovesofjuliet

Posted @withregram ‚Ä¢ @aljazeeraenglish Fifty years ago today, a war erupted in the Middle East that changed not just the region, but the world. It‚Äôs a war of many names, depending on who you ask: the October War, the Yom Kippur War, the Ramadan War, or the 1973 Arab-Israeli War.‚Å†
.‚Å†
The war‚Äôs victor is just as disputed. It began with a two-pronged attack against Israel by Egypt and Syria.‚Å†
Egypt attacked from the south, to take back the Sinai Peninsula, and Syria from the north, to take back the Golan Heights.‚Å†
.‚Å†
Israel had captured both six years prior in the 1967 Arab-Israeli war, alongside occupying what remained of historic Palestine.‚Å†
.‚Å†
The recently formed state was riding high on that victory: it never anticipated an attack like this, especially not during Yom Kippur, an auspicious day for Jews. Meanwhile, the politics of the Cold War played in the background.‚Å†
.‚Å†
The Soviets supplied the Arab countries with weapons and the United States backed Israel. The two sides were on the brink of military conflict for the first time since the so-called Cuban Missile Crisis in 1962.‚Å†
.‚Å†
üîóTap the link in bio for more.‚Å†
.‚Å†
üì∏ Daniel Rosenblum, @GettyImages/ Harry Dempster/Express, @GettyImages/ Keystone, @GettyImages / Harry Dempster/Express/Hulton Archive @GettyImages/ ‚Å†
Henri Bureau/Sygma/Corbis/VCG via @GettyImages/Ministry of Defense via @GettyImages/ Keystone/Hulton Archive, @Getty Images

On 6 October 1175, under the Treaty of Windsor, concluded on this date, the High King of Ireland Ruaidr√≠ mac Tairrdelbach Ua Conchobair, anglicised as Rory O‚ÄôConnor, recognises King Henry II of the Angevin Empire as his overlord and agrees to collect tribute for him from all parts of Ireland. 

Henry agrees that O‚ÄôConnor can be king of the areas not conquered by the Normans. 
But O‚ÄôConnor cannot control the territories of which he is nominally king, and Henry and his barons annex further land without consulting him.

Ruaidr√≠ signed the Treaty of Windsor with King Henry II of England. Whether he was unable or unwilling to, Henry did not or could not control the Norman barons, who continued conquering Irish territory, while Ruadhr√≠ could not control the lesser Irish kings. 

This led to further conflict which would continue for centuries. Ruadhr√≠ abdicated in 1183, but returned to rule briefly twice after that. Ruadhr√≠ died in the year 1198. He would be the last Gaelic king of Ireland, except for perhaps Brian Ua N√©ill (died 1260).

Brian Ua N√©ill and Edward Bruce both claimed the title of High King of Ireland with opposition in later years but their claims were considered illegitimate.

Overall, the agreement left O'Connor with a kingdom consisting of Ireland outside the provincial kingdom of Leinster (as it was then), Dublin and a territory from Waterford Dungarvan, as long as he paid tribute to Henry II, and owed fealty to him. All of Ireland was also subject to the new religious provisions of the papal bull Laudabiliter and the Synod of Cashel (1172).

O'Connor was obliged to pay one treated cow hide for every ten cattle. The other "kings and people" of Ireland were to enjoy their lands and liberties so long as they remained faithful to the kings of England, and were obliged to pay their tribute in hides through O'Connor.

The witnesses were Richard of Ilchester, Bishop of Winchester; Geoffrey, Bishop of Ely; Laurence O'Toole, Archbishop of Dublin; William, Earl of Essex; Justiciar Richard de Luci; Geoffrey de Purtico, Reginald de Courtenea (Courtenay) and three of Henry's court chaplains.

In your relationship, are you ok with asking for what you want? 

We‚Äôre not talking big things here like a new car or holiday, we‚Äôre talking about the small, everyday choices we all make. 

Asking for a specific meal for tea or asking to watch a programme that interests you that maybe your partner isn‚Äôt particularly interested in. 

These things sound small, but if you struggle to ask for these and always go along with what someone else wants, how will you ever be able to make the bigger choices and get what you want.

When we are not getting what we want, we are effectively getting what we don‚Äôt want. And how does that start to feel if it happens everyday?

Now this isn‚Äôt to say that we should all become totally unreasonable and start to demand that everything goes our way (that‚Äôs a whole other topic!) This is about compromise and team work with each other, where both of you feel seen and heard and get to enjoy the things you want more often. 

Work on overcoming your resistance to asking directly for what you want. Making a direct request for what you want allows your partner to get to know you better and know what to do if they want to treat or surprise you. This is beautiful for building a strong connection between the two of you.

What is ONE thing that you want that you could start asking for in your relationship? 

Big love ‚ô•Ô∏è

50 years ago today Yom Kippur war begins. The Yom Kippur War, or October War also known as the 1973 Arab‚ÄìIsraeli War, was a war fought from October 6 to 25, 1973, by a coalition of Arab states led by Egypt and Syria against Israel. The war took place mostly in Sinai and the Golan, occupied by Israel during the 1967 Six-Day War with  some fighting in African Egypt and northern Israel. Egyptian President Anwar Sadat's objectives were "to recover all Arab territory occupied by Israel following the 1967 war and to achieve a just, peaceful solution to the Arab-Israel conflict. #war #yomkippurwar #yomkippur #ramadan #israel #egypt #syria #1973 #1967 #golanheight #sinai #middleast #peace #jews #arabs #muslim

Posted @withregram ‚Ä¢ @talkdiplomacy Liberalism is a prominent theory in international relations that places a strong emphasis on individual and human rights, democracy, and international cooperation. It believes that the protection of human rights should be a fundamental goal in global affairs and that democratic governments tend to be more peaceful. Liberals advocate for international institutions, such as the United Nations, to facilitate diplomacy and problem-solving among states. Economic interdependence is another key concept in liberal theory, where trade and economic cooperation are seen as drivers for peace and stability. Liberals also emphasize the idea of soft power, the ability to influence others through attraction and persuasion rather than force. International law and norms play a vital role in regulating state behavior, and liberals believe that adherence to these principles can foster trust and reduce conflicts. Multilateralism is a core tenet of liberalism, with the belief that states should work together to address global challenges. Moreover, liberals recognize the importance of non-state actors, such as international organizations and non-governmental organizations, in shaping international relations. Liberal theory offers a positive outlook on the possibility of international cooperation and peaceful change, in contrast to other theories like realism, which have a more pessimistic view of international relations.

Liberalism in international relations is evident in the United Nations(UN), emphasizing diplomacy, human rights, and global cooperation. The UN's commitment to peaceful conflict resolution, adherence to international law, and protection of individual rights reflects liberal ideals in shaping the global stage for collaboration and peace. #liberalism #multilateralism #liberalideals #unitednations #talkdiplomacy #upsc #css #upscmotivation #upscaspirants #csstricks #collaboration #peace #globalaffairs #democraticgovernment #diplomacy #humanrights #cooperation #economicinterdependence #geopolitics #internationalrelationsstudent #internationalrelationstheory #peacefulchange #nonstateactors #liberaltheory #wars

This poignant photograph, captured by Anastasia Taylor-Lind in Nagorno-Karabakh in 2020 and featured in National Geographic, conveys the profound human emotions that often accompany the aftermath of conflict. In the image, a man grieves at a military cemetery in Stepanakert, the capital of Artsakh (Nagorno-Karabakh).

Meet the black bear....literally! 

What should you do in such a situation? 

‚úÖ Leave the area.
‚úÖBack away slowly: stay calm and don‚Äôt run.
‚úÖMake yourself look large; if you‚Äôre in a group, band together and raise your arms.
‚úÖTry to scare the bear by waving, yelling, banging pots, blowing air horns or making other loud noises.
‚úÖIf a bear follows you, put your pack down to distract it while you retreat.

  On the remote chance of black bear attack:

- ‚ùå Do not play dead. Playing dead may deter grizzly bears, but will not work with black bears.
-‚ùå Do not climb up a tree. Black bears are adept climbers and you will only trap yourself. Fight back. You can improve your chances of escape by launching a strong counter-attack.
-Fend off the bear any way you can.

Bear spray is not a substitute for other precautions. Always do what you can to avoid a bear encounter.

Nuisance bears are usually created by humans. Careless humans teach bears that people are easy sources of food. Poorly managed open-pit dumps, for example, are notorious training grounds for problem bears. And at home, garbage bins, dirty barbeque grills and pet food left outdoors are common bear attractants.

Changing human behaviour is the most effective way to reduce conflict relating to human-bear encounters. Be #BearWise

Applying AI to space and satellite imagery can help ground rescuers save more lives during natural disasters.

The technology can be used in hard-hit areas of conflict where access is difficult, providing usable images within hours rather than days.

This can support the hunt for survivors in times of crisis.

Society & Change Saturday Club
7 October - 16 December 2023, FREE
Join us at the National Army Museum for our weekly Society & Change Saturday Club, where young people can contribute to the debate on the future of conflict.
Our Society & Change Saturday Club offers young people, aged 13‚Äì16 years olds, a variety of different ways to contribute to the conversation on what the future of conflict looks like. 
Between 10.00am and 1.00pm every Saturday, club members will get the chance to:

‚≠ê Work with an artist to design their own piece of graphic art, taking inspiration from the Museum's archive and collections.
‚≠ê Think about how art can influence the ways we perceive conflict.
‚≠ê Build up a debate and dialogue, taking a deep dive into these questions.
‚≠ê Work with a podcast producer and Museum staff to create their own podcast episodes and record their responses.
